business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. I ask: can the minister inform the Senate how many of the 1,300 Centrelink customers whom she stated yesterday had been paid incorrectly were overpaid rather than underpaid? Can the minister inform the Senate of the value of these overpayments and whether or not they have been recovered? Can the minister also guarantee that the many honest people who reported their overpayments will not be classified as welfare cheats in the minister's next triumphant quarterly fraud and compliance report?
—It is clear that the opposition is not very keen to have documented on a regular basis the good stewardship of this government in terms of the abuse of the social security system.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Once again, Madam President, I can see that Senator West's colleagues do not want her to hear the answer. The fact is that there are very important reasons for making sure that the social security system does not fall into disrepute with those who pay for the system. Therefore this government has committed itself to making sure that people do not get paid more than they are entitled to, nor do they get paid any less.

answer.para: The Newstart common platform, which I answered questions about yesterday—the new IT system which is year 2000 compliant and which is going to be much more effective in giving immediate implementation to clients' needs compared with the longer processing that was involved with the system it has replaced—is going to mean a much better arrangement for people in the future. Nevertheless, it is correct to say—as I said yester day—that there have been some glitches with the new information technology system which are being worked on and ironed out as they go along. I congratulate those Centrelink staff who are working so hard to get the new system in place very quickly.

I am concerned, as obviously Senator West herself has been, to make sure that people who got overpaid do not get included in any statistics of people who have broken the social security law. These people have not, and they will not be included. Centrelink has given me the undertaking that they can be extracted and not produced in the figures for this quarter, which is, of course, the quarter to the end of June.

I do not believe I have the numbers of over and under, Senator—I may; if I have, I will let you know later—but certainly there were some people who were paid more and there were some people who were paid less than they were entitled to. I know that Centrelink is very sorry that people have had the inconvenience, but certainly in the administration of a new program there are always likely to be some of these problems. The previous government had them when it introduced new systems. It is not something which is specific to one brand of government over another.

These Centrelink officers have been working very hard right around Australia. They gave service through manual means to people wherever, and as soon as, the problems were discovered. Senator, I would hope that you would be as concerned as I am to see that people get what they are entitled to.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister has acknowledged that there were 1,300 underpayments and overpayments—and she will get back to us with the numbers that were under and overpaid—I further ask the minister, as I asked earlier: what is the value of these overpayments and whether they will be recovered or not?

—Any customers who might have been underpaid as a result of the system problems will be backpaid as the system fixes occur and as soon as customers identify themselves as being underpaid. Overpayments occurring from the system problems are debts to the Commonwealth and are recoverable under the Social Security Act, as they always have been. Waiver of debts arising from administrative error can be considered but only if the customer received the money in good faith and the debt is not raised within six weeks of the date of the first incorrect payment, or the customer complied with a notification obligation and the debt was not raised within six weeks from the end of the notification period.

answer.para: As I said yesterday—and as you have just used the figure again today—it is estimated that, out of an allowance population in excess of one million customers, 1,300 overpayments have occurred. The number and value of debts raised from administrative error is not included in the estimates of savings from review activity in the quarterly compliance reports tabled in parliament but the value of the debt recovered is included.

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a committee from the New Zealand parliament, the House of Representatives Health Committee, led by Mr Brian Neeson MP. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate. I trust that your talks in this country will be useful and informative and that you will enjoy your visit.
—Hear, hear!

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Since coming to office, the coalition government has initiated the largest ever environmental rescue program in Australia's history by establishing the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust. Will the minister advise the Senate of the benefits to rural and regional Australia from the trust? Have the government's efforts been supported by the Australian Labor Party?

—The Natural Heritage Trust, involving over $1 billion being invested by the Howard government in our natural resource base, is vitally important not only for the health of our environment but also for the health of our agricultural and other rural interests. It is not always appreciated that what the agricultural and rural sectors need perhaps more than anything else is a healthy natural environment and resources. We are now aware that we have significantly degraded the health of our natural systems in this country through, in some places, over-clearing and, in others, inappropriate agricultural pursuits. In other ways, too, we have degraded the health of the natural system.

answer.para: We are now, therefore, reinvesting in that natural system—our natural capital—and reinvesting more than has ever been the case in the history of this country. The Natural Heritage Trust is supporting the future prosperity of Australia's agricultural and broader rural sectors. It is important to appreciate that. We all acknowledge the difficult times for people in the bush. It is not easy these days to run a profitable farm or compete with other exports. The community in rural and regional Australia needs every support it can get, and it is getting that from the Howard government.

Out of that $1.1 billion, for example, $240 million is being invested in revegetation and protection of remnant vegetation, in other words, in protecting the health of the natural system. Over $280 million is being invested in restoration of our inland water systems—the Murray-Darling program, the national river care program, Waterwatch, et cetera. Over $360 million is being spent to address land degradation and other problems through Landcare, the national feral animal control program, the national weed strategy and the land and water resources audit.

This is the Howard government investing in rural and regional Australia. It is worth remembering that we have been knocked at every attempt, at every step, by the alternative government, the Australian Labor Party. They opposed the setting up of the trust, they opposed the sale of Telstra to provide its capital base and they have done everything possible to undermine the success of the Natural Heritage Trust and through it to undermine rural and regional Australia.

Astonishingly, after the Queensland election there has been a sudden change of mind. The Labor Party now says that it wants to use the dividends from Telstra to reinvest in rural Australia. All of a sudden the Labor Party has woken up to the bush. It is too late. For over two years they have had chances to demonstrate that they do support rural and regional Australia and they have failed to take those chances at every opportunity.

Whilst I am on my feet, I would like to congratulate Greening Australia on winning the major bush care support contract under the Natural Heritage Trust. Through this fine Australian non-government organisation, $7 million a year for three years will be used to help in the revegetation of Australia and in supporting the farmers and the rural community in what they do. For the first time in my state of South Australia, for example, Greening Australia will be doing this with a conservation organisation—the South Australian Conservation Council—and with Trees for Life. It is good to see bodies such as Greening Australia joining with conservation councils. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister give some further examples of projects through which the Natural Heritage Trust is helping rural and regional Australia?

—I would like to mention the one announced last weekend in South Australia for the Mt Lofty Ranges rehabilitation program. This is the major catchment area for Adelaide and has obviously suffered intense urban pressure over the years and is significantly degraded. Now more money is being reinvested in the health of the natural system than ever before. Under the new partnership, bodies such as Greening Australia are working with con councils on the ground. It is not just advocacy, con councils are getting out there and bringing their own communities into doing the hard work on the ground. Other fine environmental organisations such as Trees for Life will get an even better result in the future. It is good to see Greening Australia working now with private sector bodies in Western Australia to provide environmental training and also to set up a new partnership with the local government community in Western Australia to more effectively bring these major environmental programs to the community. It is a good story all round. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Newman as Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware that slow referrals from Centrelink are being cited by desperate job agencies in South Australia as one of the key factors contributing to their imminent financial collapse? What action has the minister taken to speed up the rate of referrals? What guarantees can the minister give about when these problems will be overcome, or does the minister acknowledge that the problems are systemic—an inevitable consequence of the government's draconian cuts to the former DSS work force and yet another ill conceived and fatally flawed coalition policy?

—As Senator Crowley would know very well from having attended some of the estimates committee hearings for Social Security, this is a matter which should properly be directed towards the minister responsible for employment, education, training and youth affairs as the services to which she was directing her question are those which are provided by Centrelink under contract to that department. As Centrelink has contracts with several departments, including my own of Social Security, the responsibility to answer questions on their contracts with Centrelink is placed on the shoulders of the appropriate departments and ministers who have those contracts.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We may be in danger of discovering yet another government department without any minister responsible. Given that you are the minister for Centrelink, are you concerned that your department has now slipped behind a level of critical mass, given that the computer systems are failing, those who are entitled to benefits are being denied them, others who are not entitled are being showered with overpayments and the unemployed are left in a limbo between Centrelink and the failing new job agencies? Are you asleep at the wheel, Minister, or simply not up to the job?

—Isn't it interesting that, every time one of the major unions has a campaign on, up jump their friends in the opposition pursuing the cause of the union. In this case senators would be interested to know that the CPSU is currently renegotiating their agreement with Centrelink management. Some of the questions that were asked yesterday were so inaccurate because they were based on figures which the CPSU put out in a press release a day or so ago. They were quite wrong, as I indicated yesterday with the response provided to me by Centrelink management.

answer.para: It would be a great shame if the opposition were to continue down this track because they are, first of all, making it more difficult for people who are employed in the public sector but in a statutory authority to do their job. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. What is the government doing to improve postal services in regional Australia after 13 years of neglect by the Labor Party? Is the government committed to full public ownership of Australia Post and maintaining the standard letter service at a uniform price for all Australians? Will the government's response to the National Competition Council lead to any more closures of post offices or mail centres in rural and regional Australia?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is very important to understand that we were the party that actually increased the number of rural postal deliveries within the last 12 months. Not only that, we have honoured to the letter our commitment to maintain the standard letter service at a uniform rate to all Australians. We will not be supporting the NCC recommendation that all business mail be deregulated. We certainly will ensure that regional and rural post offices and mail centres do not close as a result of our response to the NCC report. In addition to that, Australia Post has agreed to maintain a number of loss making LPOs, licensed post offices.

answer.para: We are ensuring not only that we take a sensible and balanced approach to competition issues but that we fully protect those in rural areas. That is critically important because consumers come first. Who comes first for this mob? Here it is in this photo. Look at it. What a disgusting and nauseating sight. When I first saw it I thought it was Kimbo does the limbo, but then I realised that it was really about the Leader of the Opposition dancing to the tune of the unions. In other words, the postal union says dance and he dances. It is a disgraceful example of leadership from behind. You can see from that photo who is leading the dance. It is the union movement.

What is so disgraceful is that the Labor Party has set its mind against any form of change whether or not it benefits consumers and whether or not it might be in the national interest and despite the fact that Simon Crean said only a couple of years ago in relation to reform of Australia Post: `What Labor would support is initiatives if they are to improve efficiency, as long as you guarantee the service to the remote and regional areas of this country.'

What are the facts? The facts are that, since the Labor Party corporatised Australia Post in 1989, in the six full years since 1989, there have been closures of post offices every single year, reaching a high-water mark of 134 in 1993-94, which was about the time that Labor introduced more competition in terms of reducing the protection that is available for the reserve letter service. In other words, under Labor the number of post offices closing has risen each and every year.

What has happened since we have been in government? In the first year the numbers went up by 57 and in the last full year, 1996-97, there were unbelievably 94 new postal outlets. The trend is absolutely clear: under Labor, every year the number of post offices declined in this country; under us, they have increased. They are the facts. Yet you have the cheek to get your leader out there—having his strings pulled by the puppeteers who put out press releases—saying things like, `Up to 90,000 jobs will be lost,' and, `Half the post offices in Australia will be closed.' Nothing is further from the truth.

We are the ones who are protecting rural Australia. We are the ones who are delivering the goods. You are simply pandering to the trade union movement. You are not interested in principle. You are not interested in reform. You are not interested in consumers. All you want to do is close down post offices and make sure you get some healthy donations from the CEPU at the next election. It is a very short-term strategy. It is very short-sighted. If we are going to see that gross and disgusting hypocrisy—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to a series of articles in yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser which paints an extremely disturbing picture of the government's new Job Network? Can the minister confirm the claims in that series of articles that more than half of South Australia's new job agencies are struggling to survive after seven weeks of the new system, that almost half do not have a single job listed, that no jobs have been filled in the past four weeks by 50 employment service providers in Adelaide and that the success rate on the Centrelink screen of individual employment service providers is zero per cent with a state average of zero per cent? Does the minister agree with Minister Newman that this whole mess rests at the feet of Dr Kemp?
—I am not so sure that that comment as stated by Senator Quirke is accurate or correct. Therefore, I—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order in relation to that question. I would ask that the senator withdraw it. I have not said anything of the sort about Dr Kemp.
—Order! There is an appropriate time to make personal explanations, Senator, which you may do.

—I will disregard the premise of Senator Quirke's question; it is based on an entirely false premise, as Senator Newman has just pointed out. I will go on to the fact of the matter in South Australia, and that is that there have been over 10,000 referrals of intensive assistance in South Australia. That puts it well on its way to a target of 11,000 such referrals by the end of June this year.

answer.para: I can say to Senator Quirke, through you, Madam President, that when these tenders were let to the jobs providers in South Australia—and all over the country, for that matter—they were let on the basis that it would be competitive. They were let on the basis that those providers knew what the contract would involve, and they knew that it would be competitive. As Dr Kemp has stated, it is a performance based system. These jobs providers have the job of going out and finding work for those people who are looking for it, and there is an incentive attached to that.

Nationally, the figures show that 40 per cent of the jobs found were for long-term unemployed—40 per cent of those positions found have been for long-term unemployed. That is certainly not a system that is a mess or in chaos, Senator Quirke. What we have is a total reformation of the jobs provision, jobs seeking, sector—one which is going to serve those unemployed Australians and, in fact, one which is serving unemployed Australians. The figures show that, of those who were referred, one-fifth were not on unemployment benefits, so it is working for all unemployed.

I say to Senator Quirke that, in the South Australian situation, there is a higher degree of unemployment than in other areas, and that state, despite that, still has one of the highest rates of referrals for those long-term unemployed. I think that that in itself is an indicator of a program which is succeeding. Perhaps it might help if the opposition talked it up rather than talking it down, rather than attacking a system which is delivering to the long-term unemployed.

This system has resulted in four times as many job seeking sites as there were under the old CES. This has involved over 300 new organisations taking over from the CES; organisations which are providing unemployed Australians with more opportunities, especially those long-term unemployed that I have mentioned.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister share the view of Paul Fitzgerald, the Chief Executive Officer of Job Futures, one of the four largest private job agencies, that a quarter of all the new job agencies will go broke within 12 months? If not, what is the government's prediction of the likely failure rate?

—I remind Senator Quirke that, in relation to the intensive assistance program which particularly relates to long-term unemployment, there is an up-front payment of between $1,500 and $3,000. What the government did when it let out these tenders was to offer to the private sector a competitive contract which would allow them to find unemployed people jobs and succeed at the same time. The opposition might wish to see those people go broke because they would just like to prove a political point. But, of course, this is a competitive system which will result in a benefit to those unemployed Australians.

answer.para: I can say to Senator Quirke that what we have here is a system which will deliver jobs to unemployed Australians. It will also provide a benefit to those jobs providers in their business. They will then, in their own businesses, employ Australians themselves.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's comments yesterday when he said it was `hard to deal with the Democrats' who have been `very difficult' on important issues. Minister, will you acknowledge—these are just two examples—that the government would not have had its $500 million saving by restricting overservicing by doctors or its $1.6 billion superannuation savings without our support? Would you also agree that what the Democrats have actually opposed is your government breaking its pre-election promises by doubling HECS charges, slashing social security benefits, halving the R&D tax concession and reducing child-care assistance? Will you acknowledge that a Senate that has passed 385 government bills and rejected only four—in other words, a 99 per cent pass rate—is hardly a hostile Senate?

—Regrettably, it is very difficult to negotiate with the Australian Democrats—there is no doubt about that. But I am thankful for one thing: I am thankful for their support of our industrial relations reforms. In particular, I am thankful to former Senator Kernot, as the then Leader of the Australian Democrats, who came to the table, sipped tea and decided to support this government's reforms, reforms that were designed to break down the divisions within the Australian labour market and encourage employers and employees to come together to determine terms and conditions of employment to their mutual benefit. I was pleased that former Senator Kernot, when she was Leader of the Australian Democrats, was prepared to support this government's industrial relations reforms to achieve those objectives. I only hope that, under the new leadership, they prove just as cooperative.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Therefore, I presume the minister is agreeing that he does not have a hostile Senate. I would just like to refer you to some of the Prime Minister's comments today, Minister. He said that any suggestion that he would give a wink and a nod to One Nation in the battle for the Senate is `quite wrong'. Don't you think, Minister, that the voters deserve more than just a bet each way—that they deserve a Prime Minister who stands up and says up front that he would prefer to work with a party in the Senate that holds the government to account rather than with a party which will hold the government to ransom?

—We have no preference for the far right or the far left; we have preference for neither. Senator Lees could in fact prove that we do not have a hostile Senate if she was prepared to bring the Australian Democrats to our very reasonable reforms under the Wik legislation; reforms that will provide a fair and reasonable outcome to a very difficult native title issue, but provide sufficient certainty for further investment, growth and jobs for all Australians. If the Australian Democrats were prepared to support the government in that objective, then I would say they were doing the Australian people a good service.

—My question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that one of South Australia's biggest job agency groups, with at least 23 private and community providers, has appealed to the government to pay up-front administration costs to job agencies to ensure their survival? Is the true this appeal has been backed by the South Australian Council of Social Service, the Youth Affairs Council and Adelaide University's Centre for Labour Studies? Is the government contemplating providing such assistance to agencies in South Australia and other states and territories and, if so, what is the estimated cost involved?

—I am not aware of the government making any plans to provide the assistance sought as mentioned by Senator Sherry. What I can tell Senator Sherry is that under the new system we have 154 Job Network sites, compared to 29 under the previous program involving CES. That shows a fivefold increase in job sites. We made a contract with those jobs providers and made it very clear about the services that were to be provided. We made it very clear and they tendered under that.

answer.para: It was one of the most comprehensive and fair tenders ever conducted in this country. It is performance based, as Dr Kemp has said, and these jobs providers will need to attract those people who are seeking a job and direct them accordingly, because that is where the incentive payments lie.

As I said previously, nationally 40 per cent of job placements have involved intensive assistance for the long-term unemployed. That would point to this program having a high degree of success in the very difficult area of the long-term unemployed.

The government has no regrets whatsoever about this program, which has seen a great reformation of the whole job seeking process in this country and provided unemployed Australians with greater choice.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister's answer did not go to the issue I raised about the payment of up-front administration fees to ensure the agency's survival. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the statement by a Richard Finlayson, manager of Quality Training Company with four branches in Adelaide, that the government's new system was failing `badly, very badly', and that:

question.para: . . . all of the smaller companies are in trouble. . . it looks like many of us can't survive and won't survive and the Government doesn't mind about that fact.

Does the government accept that fact? Does the government mind about that fact? And what is the government proposing to do about it, other than hoping the problem will go away or calling an election before its chickens come home to roost?

talk.start.para: —Can I make it quite clear that this government does not disregard the welfare of job seekers in this country. It does not have disregard for the success of those jobs providers. It does not in any way have any disregard in relation to this matter, as Senator Sherry alleges.

answer.para: We want to see unemployed Australians getting jobs. We want to see them have a choice of provider and we have provided that through the number of sites. We have provided that through an increased number of providers; over 300 jobs providers compared with the CES that was previously there.

I have already mentioned that in the state of South Australia we have increased fivefold the number of job seeking sites that unemployed people can go to. If that is not improving the lot of unemployed people and providing them with more opportunity, I do not know what is. This is a performance based tender. It was competitive and it is up to the individual jobs providers. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. The European Parliament has condemned the proposed uranium mine at Jabiluka in Kakadu and the head of the World Conservation Union's natural heritage program, Mr Jim Thorsell, has said that there is `a worldwide expression of alarm about what is going on' in Kakadu. The minister's office is quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald as saying that he is not concerned at all. My question is: as minister for Australia's environment, is Senator Hill going to join to world's environmental authorities in defending Kakadu from this uranium mine and our international reputation, or is he instead going to have Australia join nine other derelict nations around the world, including African dictatorships, condemned for promoting mining threats to world heritage areas?

—Senator Brown's worldwide expression of alarm is a group of between 40 and 60 demonstrators who have encamped in the Kakadu National Park. They are sourced from various areas of Australia. They have taken up temporary residence and they are expressing their democratic right, and I have no objection to that. I would prefer it if they did it a little bit more competently, because recently they chained themselves to a bulldozer, except they got the wrong bulldozer which was heading away from the mine site.

answer.para: Why I am not concerned is because this government ensured that there was a demanding environmental testing process to ensure that the new proposed mine would achieve the highest environmental standards and that process has achieved that outcome.

Of course, there has been a uranium mine and processing plant in the vicinity now for over 17 years that is operated on a basis that we are assured by the Office of the Supervising Scientist—the independent supervising authority—has no environmental detriment outside the immediate mine site. It demonstrates that, with proper engineering and sound practice, mining can occur in the vicinity of the park without causing environmental damage. We have no reason to believe that this new mine will not be of the same nature.

One should emphasise, however, that Jabiluka is not in the world heritage area. Senator Brown goes around talking about this world heritage area mine—it is not in the world heritage area and it is not in Kakadu National Park. Not only is it not located in those sensitive areas but, furthermore, we can be satisfied, by the process that has taken place, that it can be conducted in a way that is environmentally responsible. The other side of the ledger of course is further wealth for Australia. Further jobs for many Australians, money for the Aboriginal people of the local Aboriginal communities, are the ways in which Australians can benefit from development which is being conducted in an environmentally sensible way.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What rearguard action has the minister taken to try to defend the indefensible before the World Heritage Bureau, which is meeting in Paris at the moment? Is he aware that Yvonne Margarula and other representatives of the Mirrar people are in Paris to put the case of the danger to the world heritage cultural values, as well as the environmental values, of the uranium mine? Does he really not care about the damage to Australia's international reputation if Kakadu is put on the world heritage endangered list because of this obscene mine?
—In 1982 the Aboriginal traditional owners agreed to the mine at Jabiluka.
—Different mine.
—Agreed to this mine at Jabiluka, Senator Bolkus. Go back—some differences in the method of mining, some differences in the method of processing, but the Jabiluka mine was approved in 1982.

answer.para: There are some traditional owners that now oppose the mine. One has been mentioned by Senator Brown as going overseas to protest it, as is her right. The Aboriginal community are divided on the mine. I concede that. Some fear. But the predominant concern for them is not Senator Brown's environment concern but a concern about the social pressures and other social downsides of increasing employment and the presence of growing numbers of people in the Kakadu and mining vicinity—not the environmental issue that Senator Brown is talking about at all.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Justice. Minister, isn't it true that your government has already cut more than $1.6 million in 1996 dollar terms from the Australian Federal Police operations in South Australia, reducing the AFP staff from 94 to just 60, and that the government has also reduced the National Crime Authority's presence in South Australia from 33 staff to 13? Minister, haven't these cuts reduced the ability of our federal law enforcement agencies to stop drugs coming into South Australia? Will you now concede that the government's inappropriately named Tough on Drugs strategy is actually failing the people of your own state?

—I thank Senator Bolkus for yet again a question from heaven—an opportunity to point out what this government has done that the previous government failed to do. I do not know what sort of pills he is on, but I hope he has got a long prescription for them. I look forward to this opportunity every day.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus asks me questions in relation to funding of the Federal Police and of the National Crime Authority, and seeks information specifically in relation to South Australia. We know that the opposition does not want to tell the truth to the Australian community. They want to use question time to mislead the community as to what this government has done in the same way that when they were in government they misled the community as to what they were doing.

Senator Bolkus fails to mention a number of things. Firstly, in relation to funding of the Australian Federal Police, the situation in which the previous government left the Australian Federal Police was not satisfactory. The Prime Minister has recognised that and earlier this year—I think in January or February—told an international Interpol conference that he was personally determined to see that the Australian Federal Police would be a federal police force second to none. As a consequence of his decision, the Ayers review was set up to review the basis of Federal Police funding, to ensure that we can put the Federal Police on a financial standing and a basis for funding that will allow it to meet the challenges of law enforcement in the 21st century.

Senator Bolkus also fails to mention that the nearly $200 million Tough on Drugs initiative gives nearly $100 million to law enforcement, distributed through the Federal Police, through the National Crime Authority, through Customs and through Austrac.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting.

—Money is made available through Austrac for chasing money laundering in relation to drugs. He neglects to mention this input of additional money to fight drugs. He neglects specifically to mention the mobile strike teams for the Federal Police, targeted specifically at drug traffic coming into Australia, that have been funded by the Tough on Drugs initiative. He fails to mention them because he knows they are called mobile strike teams for a particular purpose, and that purpose is quite clear in their name. They might be based in Sydney—three of them are there—with one in Brisbane, one in Melbourne and one in Perth. But those teams will go where the intelligence tells them the best opportunity to stop drugs coming into Australia is to be found. If the intelligence shows that there is a reason to shift those teams for a particular period of time to South Australia or Western Australia, or to Melbourne, that is where they will go.

answer.para: Law enforcement should not be based on pork barrelling of one state or another, it should be based on where the intelligence tells us we can catch the drug runners. They are the changes that this government has made and is happy to stand behind.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister does not deny the fact that resources to the NCA and the AFP are less than what they were two years ago. Is the minister aware of the following comments made by the South Australian Commissioner of Police, Mr Hyde, in respect of the South Australian police force:

question.para: We are very concerned about the reduction in resources to some of the Federal agencies, particularly in the area of drugs . . . We cannot put all our resources into shoring up the Commonwealth's withdrawal of resources from those Federal agencies.

Minister, how do you justify your answer and how do you justify this obscene assertion that what I am about is pork barrelling? Isn't the Commissioner of Police in South Australia, Mr Hyde, correct when says you have withdrawn resources and they are in no position to shore up your failure of responsibility?

talk.start.para: —Law enforcement, as with so many other Commonwealth areas, is a shared responsibility. I am sure people opposite who have the opportunity to be minister would understand, as I think all school children understand, that when there are shared responsibilities there is a sharing of the blame and there is a sharing of the fame. It has been my experience that, whenever any drugs are located as a consequence of a cooperative initiative between the National Crime Authority, the Federal Police and a state police force, the first people out to the paper to say `20 kilos of drugs have been seized' are always the state police. I do not mind their doing that. When they have made a contribution to a joint effort, why should they not get such publicity as they can for that? We see it in health, we see it in education, we see it in so many other areas. Of course the state police forces will always want Commonwealth law enforcement agencies to have more money. Of course they will want to share the responsibility, the shame where it is not good enough and the fame where it is.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Senator Parer would of course be aware that our resource industries employ hundreds of thousands of Australians as a result of billions of dollars in investment in rural and regional Australia. That investment also provides the federal government each year with some $6,000 million of taxation revenue which is used to provide services for all Australians. My question to the minister is this: what effect would the implementation of different investment policies have on our resource industries? Most importantly, what impact would it have upon the jobs and the livelihoods of people in rural and regional Australia?

—I would like to thank Senator O'Chee for that question. He would realise, as many people on our side recognise, that the minerals and energy sector continues to be one of the great success stories for regional and rural Australia. At the moment there are no less than 122 major projects under way or committed around Australia collectively worth $24,000 million and a further 174 projects worth in excess of $75,000 million. I could not help noticing the other day Senator Lees from the Democrats claim that the real election battle will be between the Democrats and One Nation. But I ask the Senate to consider what the One Nation policies are. They are tariff barriers, restriction of foreign investment, reduced immigration and no privatisation.

answer.para: I ask the Senate: what is the battle? The fact is that One Nation has adopted exactly the same populist policies which have for so long been the trademark of the Australian Democrats. One Nation are the Democrat camp followers on the road to lost job opportunities, particularly in regional Australia, the very area they claim to champion. I will give the Senate some examples. Look at the northern Australian gas venture; a $10 billion project to bring gas through on the Timor Sea to Darwin for export to Asia and to develop a new pipeline network across northern Australia to regional and east coast markets. Look at the Papua-New Guinea to Gladstone pipeline, something one of the Queensland Democrats questioned. He questioned it, but think of the benefits that are going to come from this. This will create 1,800 jobs during construction right down the Queensland coast and a new environmentally friendly gas fired power station in Townsville, which I understand was just signed up yesterday, a good chance of a billion dollar alumina refinery in Gladstone, enormous business opportunities right along the Queensland coast from Cape York to Gladstone.

Last week I was in Burnie to reassure the 200 people who took the time to attend the public meeting organised by local member Chris Miles—and I acknowledge the presence at that meeting of Senator Sherry. The purpose of the meeting was to show the people of Burnie that the Howard government stands squarely behind the development of a new magnesite mining and processing plant in north-west Tasmania and to tell them that we helped to bring gas from the Yolla gas field or other base rate fields to onshore Tasmania. We were there to tell them we will immediately put up to $300,000 into infrastructure planning, as we have in regional centres in other states. Not one person there opposed this project. They were absolutely enthusiastic about it because of the potential to create jobs. But, again, who do we have? The lone voice of Senator Brown opposing a project which would bring tremendous benefits to the regional part of north-western Tasmania. Real jobs, putting people first in a regional part of Australia.

In Western Australia the Dampier to Kalgoorlie pipeline will soon lower by one-third the cost of household power to 95 per cent of households in the region and new mines and new processing plants under development down the pipeline route. Look at the recent announcement of the Minerva gas project in offshore Warrnambool, a new fertiliser plant in Geelong, $700 million worth of investment, thousands of construction jobs and thousands of permanent jobs once this project comes into fruition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Minchin, representing the Minister for Sport and Tourism. I refer to Minister Thomson's recent buck-passing in relation to funding for the Australian paralympic athletes from the Olympic athlete program. Can the minister confirm that, rather than Mr Thomson making a decision himself, he has shifted the onus onto the Australian Sports Commission by announcing a review of funding for paralympians? Is the minister aware that, despite the enormous success that our paralympians achieved at the Atlanta Games, their revenue options are extremely limited because of the selling of their marketing rights and the requirements of the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Act 1996? When will the minister acknowledge that the government's priorities are wrong and intervene to do more than simply shift the blame and waste valuable training opportunities in the meantime?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I have a brief on the preparations for the 2000 Paralympics, which I am pleased to advise the honourable senator of. Any additional information I will have to get for her and take on notice.

answer.para: I am advised that, in relation to preparations for the 2000 Paralympic Games, the Australian Sports Commission has provided assistance totalling $2.7 million under the Olympic athlete program since 1994-95 for the preparation of our elite athletes with disabilities for the 2000 Paralympics. These funds have been used for purposes such as elite coaching, international competition, training camps and sports science and medicine support. A further $2 million is to be provided for this purpose over the next two financial years.

It is true that the Australian Paralympic Committee has expressed concern about inequities in government funding between able-bodied and disabled sport, citing the different levels of Olympic athlete program funding to prepare athletes for the 2000 Olympics and Paralympics. The government recognises that sport for the disabled does not enjoy the membership base or commercial opportunities available to many of the able-bodied sports, nor does it enjoy the same level of financial support enjoyed by many Olympic sports under the OAP.

Nevertheless, the ASC must determine what is the appropriate share of available funds to each eligible organisation, and Minister Thomson understands that this is being done by examining issues such as potential for success in 2000 and the needs of the athletes in order to achieve this success. We have yet to learn about the level of funds the APC intends to commit to athlete preparation from its income from the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee—that is, for marketing rights—and fund raising efforts to comple ment the government's contribution to the paralympic preparation program.

The APC and ASC met on 15 June 1998 to discuss the needs of the paralympic preparation program; and on the 16th and 17th the APC and commission staff met to commence a review of the plans and budgets of each paralympic sport for 1998-99. Further assessment of plans and budgets identifying the needs of each sport through to 2000 will be made following the completion of world championships in 1998. This will ensure that we can all be confident about the appropriateness of the plans and their costings.

At this time the APC and commission are due to meet again on 14 July to consider the progress made. Minister Thomson has met with the APC and is now awaiting advice from the commission about the appropriate level of assistance to our paralympic athletes. The commission has determined that at this time an annual allocation from the OAP of $1 million for paralympic preparation is reasonable.

It must be recognised that, if further OAP funds are made available to the APC, some Olympic sports must do with less for their preparations. For this reason, the ASC needs to satisfy itself about the plans of all sports and the current review of Olympic sports will not be completed before November.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. You have confirmed certainly the buck-passing and the inequitable funding arrangements for our paralympians. But can the government also confirm that public funding by this government for Australian sport as a whole has been cut by $20 million over four years? Isn't this just another example of the Howard government getting its priorities wrong in that the government funding for sports participation and community level activity has been cut at the very time we should be using the 2000 games as motivation to get involved in healthy activities?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the budget allocation for the Australian Sports Commission in the coming year will be $89.3 million, a near record level of funding. The government gave a commitment when we came to office that this level of funding would be maintained through until the Sydney Olympics, and we have honoured that commitment.

answer.para: So I think the government has demonstrated a very significant commitment of taxpayers' funds to the program through to the 2000 Olympics. Madam President, as you and the senator would know from the estimates committees, of course the government has to develop a forward program from the year 2000 onwards, and it will do that through the normal budgetary process.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: does the minister agree with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, that Australia's influence in South-East Asia should be maximised to improve our security? Does the minister agree with senior officials from China, Malaysia, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, as well as Bishop Belo of East Timor and Mr Alan Greenspan of the US Federal Reserve, who all nominated Radio Australia's short-wave service as the most valuable or essential to them in the region? Is the minister aware of the six heads of state from Asian nations who wrote to the Prime Minister requesting that Radio Australia's short-wave service be continued? Finally, has the government decided to sell for scrap Radio Australia's state-of-the-art short-wave transmitter in Darwin, even though it would cost only $1.8 million a year to return Radio Australia to South-East Asia?

—Madam President, this is a debate we have had a number of times before. We, as you know, modified the coverage of Radio Australia to areas that we believed were still of relevance to that form of transmission. It was our opinion that areas into South-East Asia no longer required short wave because of access to communications through more popular methods—normal radio being an obvious example.

answer.para: As I said, on that basis, the honourable senator knows that we decided to no longer transmit short wave in that direction. And I think it is true that the facility that has been closed is now being sold off.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you telling us that you believe South-East Asia is not still of relevance to Australia—is that what you are saying? Alternatively, are you telling us that you believe the majority of people in South-East Asia can get Radio Australia through satellite rather than through short-wave transmitters; or do you believe that they do not deserve to hear Radio Australia, which all these people have nominated as being the most valuable or the most essential in the region?

—Of course I did not say that the region is not of relevance to Australia; it is of utmost relevance to Australia. What I am saying is that the method of communication that the honourable senator is talking about is no longer of the same relevance. There are so many different methods of communication now available within the region. As the honourable senator is a traveller, she would know: anywhere in South-East Asia now, there is a myriad of alternative methods of communication.

answer.para: That is the point we have made—that times have changed, and there is no longer the need to send short wave into that region as there once was in the past. In areas of the Pacific where there is still that need, we continue to so transmit.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. The Weekend Australian reported that:

question.para: . . . the Howard Government's multi-billion dollar private health insurance incentive scheme is headed for a spectacular failure, with coverage already 500,000 shy of the target set for its first year of operation.

Is that true? Can the minister confirm that 334,000 people have abandoned private health insurance over the last two years? Can the minister also confirm that the level of private health insurance has already fallen to 31 per cent, whereas the government promised to raise coverage from 32 per cent to 35.5 per cent by 30 June this year? Finally, is it not the case, Minister, that the government's policy is not heading for a spectacular failure, rather, that it already is a spectacular failure?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —To the first question: no. To the second question: no, I cannot. There are about four other questions that I have lost track of in seriatim order. The general premise is that the changes that we brought in in private health insurance are heading for a spectacular failure. Imagine what would have happened if we had not brought them in? Private health insurance would be $30 a month more for a family because the deliberate policy of the Labor government was to destroy private health insurance.

answer.para: At least we did something to try to slow the fall. It was inevitable, with the ageing population and the cost of private health care, that it was going to fall, as it has done. It fell spectacularly under the Labor government. It went from 70 per cent when they came to power to less than 40 per cent. It has slowed, and I keep telling Senator Forshaw the rate of the fall is slowing. In Queensland, for example, it has been virtually static for 13 years, and that is what will occur.

Senator Forshaw, I make a confident prediction to you once again that it will slow. The fall has been shown to be at a lesser rate since we introduced this policy. It will not be a spectacular failure. Private health insurance premiums under this government are up to $450 cheaper than they would otherwise have been.
Opposition senators interjecting—Ha, ha!

talk.start.para: —Did I hear a laugh from the other side? That was acknowledged by their leader—by Mr Beazley, nonetheless. The Labor Party ought to see what their own leader says because Mr Beazley, in fact, acknowledged that it has been $450 cheaper under us than it would have been under the Labor Party, so I do not accept that statement.

answer.para: We would have loved to have put more money in, Madam President, but you will recall that we faced a $10½ billion deficit when we came into office—the previous seven budgets had a $70 billion deficit over the previous seven years. We would have loved to have put more money in, we would have loved to have helped private health insurance, because the facts of the matter are we want freedom of choice in this country that allows people to go to the public hospitals or to the private hospitals and not be dominated by the cost.

The changes that the Labor Party brought in meant that there was a spectacular fall in private health insurance and an inevitable overloading of the public hospital system—this is what we have picked up. For 13 years they tried to destroy it. We are trying to resurrect the system so that we come back to that balance. It will not occur overnight; it will take some time. We are putting things like billing procedures into place so that the patient will get one bill instead of multiple bills. There are many things occurring that will revive the private health insurance industry in this country and they certainly will not come from the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —Minister, I did not ask you for a prediction; I, in fact, referred you to the prediction of the Minister for Health and Family Services in your government.
—Senator, you should address your remarks to the chair.

—Madam President, the minister said that the rate of coverage would actually increase by 30 June of this year. I ask a supplementary question of the minister. Is it not true that the government's private health insurance rebate—totalling $1.7 billion over three years—has already been eaten up by the increase in private health insurance premiums—increases far in excess of the increases in the previous two years before you came to government? Further, isn't the minister prepared to admit what is now glaringly obvious—that this expensive scheme is an abysmal failure?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —This 40 per cent figure was a figure that Access Economics produced before the election, which has been latched on to, which the opposition now says was a figure that we predicted would occur. Nobody has got a crystal ball; nobody knows what is going to happen tomorrow, let alone what will occur in six months' time.
—You just made a confident prediction.

—I have made a confident prediction that it will plateau. I have never said what that figure will be, because I don't know any more than the opposition knows. To come back to the point of the supplementary question: no, I do not believe it has been a spectacular failure. It is inevitable that premiums rise because two-thirds of the health care dollar are spent on people over the age of 65; there is a disproportionate number of older people in private health insurance who are taking more out of it than they are contributing; and there are not enough younger people. All these fact are known to the public and, if the public knows them, at least Senator Forshaw should. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked by Senator Quirke and Senator Crowley today, relating to employment services in South Australia and Centrelink.

I would like to start by, first of all, passing comment on the non-answers—I think is the appropriate term—given by Senator Newman today, who, it turns out, is only the Minister for Social Security and not actually the minister for Centrelink or something like that. Or is it that Centrelink has contracts to other agencies that she does not know anything about, or that it is the wrong minister, or whatever? It was so contorted that it was very difficult to tell. So far as the opposition is concerned, as far as we can determine, Senator Newman is, in fact, the Minister for Social Security and also the minister for Centrelink, so we expect that when Senator West actually asks questions with regard to Centrelink, we would get some kind of response—but, oh no.

talk.start.para: —She blames her officials.

—She always blames the officials, blames the Public Service, or it is not her portfolio, or it is some other minister, or she will have to seek advice from somewhere else, or whatever. The bottom line is: she is the Minister for Social Security and the minister for Centrelink.

speech.para: Let me turn to Senator Ellison. When John Howard gave his pep talk to his front bench yesterday about question time, about being concise and actually answering questions, obviously he did not include Senator Ellison in that. We did not get any response at all to the questions that we asked, in a situation where Senator Ellison should have been across the issues and should have been able to advise the Senate what the government is doing about this parlous situation in South Australia.

I will not go through all the sad, sorry history in relation to this, but I will say this. First of all, job agencies have not been told the truth by this government with regard to the tendering process. It goes back to the very beginning when they initially put their tenders in. They were told to actually tender for all three FLEXes, a mix of FLEX 1, 2 and 3. When the results came out, the situation was that some agencies had FLEX 1, some had FLEX 2, some had FLEX 3 and some extremely lucky ones had a mix of all three FLEXes. But the job agencies themselves had put their budgets together based on a mix of all three. When the results came down, the successful job agencies said, `That is fine. I have got X amount of FLEX 3, X amount of FLEX 1 or whatever, and I will be able to budget.' But no. What happens? Centrelink referrals do not come. Centrelink has a ceiling—what the government likes to call a target is in fact a ceiling—in terms of referrals. There is absolutely no doubt that this whole situation is a shonk and is rotten to the core.

Let us have a look at the Centrelink Web page. If you were a South Australian job seeker, for example, and you wanted to find out which job agency you might want to go to and you were interested in having a look at a job agency that had a reasonable success rate in South Australia, what would you do? You might think that the Centrelink Web page would tell you want the success rate of various job agencies is. You would be sadly disappointed, because right down the relevant column it says zero, zero, zero. And it is not just in South Australia that it says zero; in every single state in Australia it says zero. Why is this? We were in estimates last week, and the government has decided quite deliberately not to release the results of the success rates for job agencies until just before the election. That is the decision that this government has made. When I questioned the secretary of the department, he said, `Don't ask me—it is a government decision.' So this government, which is all about so-called choice, is actually going to wait until just before the election until it advises job seekers about information which may assist them with regard to choice. We all know why: because they want to make themselves look good and they want to make the statistics look good.

What we have here is a situation where job agencies, many of them community based, which have been doing an excellent job, budgeted based on the amount of FLEX they would get—not an unreasonable situation, I would have thought. It turns out that the drip-feed from the government via Centrelink is just not working. Mr Sedgwick, who is the secretary of the department, said very clearly in the estimates, `We never promised anybody a living.' Dr Kemp has said, `If you are no good, you won't survive.' I say to the government that it is a bit late to tell these poor job agencies, which have basically budgeted on the fact that they were going to get income, that they are not going to get that income and they will not survive. I think the estimate of 25 per cent is actually very conservative. I think this government knows this and I think it is deliberately starving some of these agencies of funds. At the end of the 19-month period of the first tender round, we will have at least 25 per cent go under. What will we have left? We will have four or five, including Employment National, which is getting $130 million worth of taxpayer funds, thank you very much, and which refuses to answer questions, incidentally, with regard to the appropriations in estimates. The government knows this. This is just a pyrrhic exercise and one whereby job agencies have been clearly misled. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Once again we see a response on questions by Labor Party senators today that shows their paranoia on anything that is to do with change, and particularly anything that is to do with change from a position which they formerly held in government. They seem to think that the world was created during a period of Labor administration that was idyllic and special. Let me assure the Senate that the systems that were created by the Labor Party were hopeless. They were in chaos when we came to government and there were areas that needed very significant change. I am very pleased that both my minister, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) and Senator Ellison in this place as Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training have addressed these particular issues.

speech.para: The initial question asked by Senator West this afternoon related to Centrelink's new computer system, which was installed this year on 12 May. But let me point out that that was replacing a legacy of ageing equipment that was lousy and useless and was not catching up with the particulars at any particular time. What do we now see? We see a concerted attack by the Labor Party apologists, along with the union organisation groups who are so reluctant because they are negotiating new terms and conditions for themselves and are not willing to be part of representing an improvement to the system.

Yes, there have been a number of issues that have arisen with regard to the systems being put in place, and we have acknowledged that a number of those issues do need to be addressed, as happens with any new system. But I point out that the new system has produced far less recorded problems than the old system at the time of any changeover in this particular portfolio. That is particularly relevant in so many of these areas that we are currently addressing. The implementation of many of the Howard government's new policies has picked up a number of new programs meeting and mixing millions of customers throughout Australia. Millions of Australians are being affected. We have acknowledged that the consequences of change to the computer systems need to be further addressed, but the actual numbers involved are in the order of 100, 500 or 1000. They are incidental in the total number of cases, and they are all being addressed within one or two days of the implementation of any of these particular changes. I think it is an insult by the Labor Party to the Centrelink staff and to the staff of the various client government departments of Centrelink, whether it is DEETYA, Social Security, Health and Family Services or the other departments. It is the Labor Party that is now sledging the staff of Centrelink in all of these areas in identifying the problems.

It is very important to note what the objective is that we are seeking to do. It is a better service to be provided to customers at the time of the update of both the policy and the administration. There are considerable processing efficiencies to be gained and finances to be obtained. The systems that are being implemented are much more integrated, and the vast majority of customers are correctly paid on time. Let me reinforce that point: the vast majority of customers are correctly paid on time. The minority—the very small numbers—that have been affected by administrative errors will certainly be picked up as quickly as possible where there is any need for backpayment and, where adjustments have to be made for overpayment, they will be handled carefully, sensitively and appropriately, as you would expect in any area of accountability.

I was surprised that Senator Mackay does not understand the role of Centrelink. Centrelink is a service delivery agency. It is a new administrative advance that is far superior to anything that the Labor Party ever implemented in 13 years of government. The number of customers it has throughout Australia is remarkable—millions and millions across a number of government departments. The client departments are Social Security, DEETYA, Health and Family Services—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think we should get back to the question, or at least some of the key bits of it. I asked the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs a series of questions about what is rapidly becoming a disaster. In part, that question was: `Can the minister confirm the claims that more than half of South Australia's new job agencies are struggling to survive after seven weeks of the new system?' Almost half do not have a single job listed. No jobs have been filled in the past four weeks by 50 employment service providers in Adelaide. The success rate on the Centrelink screen of individual employment service providers is zero per cent, with a state average of zero per cent.

speech.para: In the supplementary question, I went a bit further. I asked the minister if he shared the view of Paul Fitzgerald, the chief executive officer of Job Futures—one of the four largest private job agencies—that a quarter of all the new job agencies will go broke within 12 months.

Those were the key salient bits. What answers did I get? To the first part—that, after seven weeks, the agencies are struggling—we got no answer. I was waiting to find out that the Adelaide Advertiser had got it wrong and that we had got it wrong. But no, I did not get that. I was waiting to find out how many jobs have been filled in the past four weeks by 50 employment service providers in Adelaide. I can only presume that the Adelaide Advertiser is absolutely accurate. I was waiting to find out that the success rate on the Centrelink screen of individual employment service providers is not zero per cent. I would not have been very happy if it were one, two, four, five or 10 per cent but, at zero per cent, there is absolutely no way you can put a decent face on that.

We found out that the state average was also zero per cent. We found that out quite easily because the minister this afternoon answered everything except what was put to him, and that was to tell us that this sorry picture that is emerging is not true—that we got it wrong or that the Adelaide Advertiser got it wrong. What we expected, and what I had hoped for, was that there was going to be some glimmer of hope given by any of the ministers who were asked questions about this sorry tale of human carnage. We hoped they would tell us that this stuff is really not accurate and that there are people out there who are finding employment.

I have not been in this place as long as many others but I am puzzled at how this government makes decisions. This was one of the stranger decisions that was made. As an old state member, the first thing I do every day is to flick to the obituaries in the Adelaide Advertiser to see who has passed away.

talk.start.para: —The votes of the dead ones, eh?

—I have a look through that to see if any of my old constituents are no longer able to vote for me, and do you know what is next to it? The dating agencies. Then I realised where they got their policy from. This is just a different form of dating agency. Senator Patterson is trying to interrupt my speech, and she may need the services of this crowd before too much longer. It may well be that she will have a vested interest—she and Senator Synon—in how this whole system is going to work. I have to tell the senator that unfortunately there is only a couple of months for her to brush up before she may be needing these services.

speech.para: At the end of the day, I want to confirm that I think this government must be a bunch of romantics. The only way they could have picked up this scheme is from the idea that there are so many jobs—more than enough for all the people out there—that all we have to do is to get some super-dating agency going so that we can bring them together. What we will do—we are so miserable with money, as Senator Crowley pointed out to me before—is wait until they are happily wedded before they get their money. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We know why the Labor Party looks at the obituaries. We know in Eden- Monaro they spent their whole time looking at the obituaries to find out who had died so they could actually have dead men voting. I can understand why the Labor Party is very interested in reading obituaries. That is their tactic: vote early, vote often and also have dead people voting. So I can understand why Senator Quirke reads the obituaries.

speech.para: Senator Mackay was loose with the truth. She said that Senator Newman is always blaming the public servants. That is totally untrue. That is not what Senator Newman does, and to say that Senator Newman is blaming the public servants was absolutely an outrageous statement. But as for being loose with the truth, the shadow minister for family services, the member for Jagajaga, Jenny Macklin, is also loose with the truth. I can go through her press releases one after the other and there they are—exaggerations, frightenings and scaremongering. In her press release about Centrelink, she says:

Thousands of people have received social security benefits that they are not entitled to in yet another example of the Howard government's failure to halt the chaos in the delivery of employment services.
She says, `thousands of people'. There is not even logic in the press release because later on in the third last paragraph she says:
The Labor opposition calls on Senator Newman to report how many people received money that they were not entitled to and how much money was involved.

She has told us up the top—`thousands'—but she was wrong. But Jenny Macklin does not let the truth get in the way of a good story or in the way of frightening older people about nursing homes or pensions or Telelink. She just spurts out any old thing that comes into her head—`thousands of people' have not got it. Senator Newman has told us today that it was something like 1,300 people out of over one million clients who have had a problem with payments from Centrelink, that they have been identified, that they are being corrected and that the overpayments will not be included in the assessment of the overpayments that have been recovered.

Labor senators who have spoken in this debate did not talk about what has happened since the coalition has been in government. They did not talk about Senator Newman's press release of 7 April on her report on compliance and the crackdown on social security fraud. They did not bother to tell the public that since July 1996 some $600 million—or nearly $1.1 million a day—has been recovered for the taxpayer in respect of overpayments. We have not seen ACOSS and social security recipients marching in the street because this money has been taken from people who were not entitled to those benefits. It is money that taxpayers have paid into the system.

In the last year of the Labor government we were $10 billion overspent, and $1.1 billion was in overpayments. We were borrowing money from overseas—borrowing money from foreigners—to pay people social security benefits to which they were not entitled. We were borrowing money against the children of the future—the children of the next generation—to pay people social security benefits to which they were not entitled.
Senator Lundy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Lundy is squarking and interjecting. It was borrowing from her children to pay people social security benefits to which they were not entitled—$1.1 million a day. The Labor Party hates to hear us saying this, and I will say it over and over again. Senator Newman is saving $1.1 million a day, $28 million a week, over $1 billion a year in money that was going to people who were defrauding the social security system, to people who were in receipt of money that they should not have had. We are about giving social security to the needy, not to the greedy.

speech.para: We are saving that sort of money as a result of the reforms that Senator Newman has brought in. She has been able to do some things. However, one thing that has just been knocked back in the Senate is a benefit to parents caring for profoundly disabled children. But, no, the Labor Party wanted to spend more money and knocked it back. The Labor Party and the Democrats have deprived those parents of profoundly disabled children the benefit of some of the money that Senator Newman has been able to save. But they do not tell us about that. They are prepared to stand up here and tell outrageous lies, as Jenny Macklin did—giving false figures about the number of people who have been affected. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise and follow Senator Patterson on this matter. It is not an outrageous lie, Senator. Your minister has already pointed out that some 1,300-plus people have been wrongly paid.
—Thousands and thousands.

—It is all very well to say that is only 1,300 out of one million. How would you like to be one of those people whose money did not come? How would you like to be one of those unemployed people who, through no fault of their own, have nothing this week because their money did not come? How would you like to be one of those people who were overpaid through no fault of their own? Suddenly the money is being paid back and the minister will be claiming that they were welfare cheats. No, they were not; they were errors by the department—by this new Centrelink system.

speech.para: Senators opposite should take serious note of what is being said. This is not the Labor Party; this is the Advertiser in South Australia and, as Senator Hill would know, it is not known as a hot-to-trot Labor Party rag. No, indeed; it is much more likely to be a cautious, conservative newspaper. So when it is writing an article that absolutely savagely and scathingly criticises the job network and the new job system in South Australia, you should be paying great heed. Why are you not admitting that the system is totally chaotic and a total failure for the people it is meant to help?

It is not providing jobs for the so-called FLEX 1 and 2. In fact, all Senator Ellison can tell us is that the long-term unemployed are getting jobs. That is something we would all be very pleased about. But the people who are not able to get jobs—the people who are FLEX 1 and FLEX 2 as they say—are not being provided with any assistance or any jobs at all. More importantly, all the job agencies that were successful in their tendering bids are about to go under. What does Minister Kemp say on behalf of the Liberal government? `Do your job or you die.' The Adelaide Advertiser said:
The federal Employment Minister, Dr Kemp, last night shrugged off the concerns of struggling South Australian job agencies, telling them: `If you perform, you'll thrive.'
And he has rejected claims that some job agencies have not received one single referral under the newly privatised Job Network scheme.

What is he doing—calling all these people liars? Is that what he is saying to the job agencies whom he has appointed to do this job? They know they are not getting any money. They have a massive failure of any capital. They have no referrals. Centrelink is not providing the information to them, and it is a complete and utter stuff-up. That is the problem. People are not getting assistance with jobs and the centre providers are not going to survive.

What are you planning to do about that? According to Mr Howard and Dr Kemp, you—the so-called caring, compassionate government—are not going to take the slightest notice of them. There is supposedly nothing to take any heed of—`No, the system's there. Fix it. And if you don't survive, too bad.' That is hardly a way to encourage the unemployed or the providers of employment.

As the chair of the regional unemployment inquiry, I have heard and some of my colleagues have heard—Senator Ferris, for example, knows this full well—the evidence that we are getting from around Australia that many of those Job Network systems are not falling into place: they are a terrible mess. People are being referred for miles to attend an agency that will assist them with a job, only to find that, even if they are on those books at last, there is no job. They have had to travel a huge distance at great cost only to find that if they do not go to that place they cannot get a job or a referral anywhere else. People are just giving up in droves.

This is a total mess.
