I am surprised that you do not admit there are major teething problems with this and that it would be much better to be saying, `Yes, there are problems and we are out there seriously reviewing what's going wrong,' and perhaps paying some of these agencies money up-front to allow them to survive. But no, Dr Kemp—on behalf of the so-called caring, Liberal government—says, `If you don't survive, too bad. You're in or you're out, and it's up to you to pull your fingers out and get the jobs going.' But it is not up to them at all: they are waiting for referrals from Centrelink and the Centrelink referrals are not coming. We should be very concerned that a new system that was put in place to be so-called better than the old one is a total failure. It is chaos, confusion and anxiety out there. People are hurting badly.

Mr Howard and his government say that they are listening to people in rural and regional Australia. But, on the minister's evidence, they are totally deaf on this issue. People cannot get employment. People are very concerned about how they now have to go through this process to try to get employment, and it is simply not working. The jobless fill out new social security forms, wait for job seeker identification numbers, fill out more forms to link with private employment services and still nothing happens. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Crowley and Senator Quirke have extensively quoted today from a story in the Advertiser headed `Job centre's crisis'. The main thing that is truthful about this article is the heading. If you take out the word `centre's', you pretty well sum up the problem of South Australia in relation to unemployment under the previous government: `Job crisis'.

speech.para: There is no doubt that, as Senator Crowley has said, South Australia—like many other states in this country—is still suffering from the long-term unemployment legacy that this government inherited 2½ years ago. I am surprised to hear Senator Quirke and Senator Crowley so extensively quote from the Advertiser article as if it is fact and not fiction. I am very interested to hear that Senator Crowley and Senator Quirke believe everything that they read in the Advertiser, because the reality, on this occasion, is certainly far from the truth.

Before I get onto that, let us take a moment to think about why we have this new process: why we have Job Network and why we decided to change the arrangements under which thousands and thousands of our young people in Australia were reluctant to get out of bed in the morning, then spent the day in front of the television set—while their parents were despairing of a future for them—or spent the day going out to the video shop because they felt that they had absolutely no future. What they have now got under Job Network is access to more than 1,400 sites around Australia—four times the number of CES sites that were previously available.

talk.start.para: —They haven't got any telephones—they can't be found.

—Senator Carr says they have not got any jobs. The one thing that is right about your statement, Senator Carr, is that it goes back 10 years and more: they had no jobs under your government and they had no chance of finding them. With our new Job Network arrangements, at least they have a chance at those 1,400 sites around Australia of looking for extra job vacancies.

speech.para: Let us turn now to the accusations made in the Advertiser. The article in the Advertiser suggested that Job Network was about to collapse in my state of South Australia. My inquiries enable me to refute that suggestion completely. Performance data shows that there have been over 10,000 job referrals for intensive assistance in South Australia since 1 May. They are well on track to achieve the 11,000 target set for the end of June. The data shows that, in fact, there is no site in South Australia which has not had a referral. Each referral to intensive assistance results in a follow-up, up-front payment to the member of the Job Network ranging from $1,500 to $3,000, depending on how disadvantaged the job seeker is and the amount of assistance that is needed to help them find a job.

This government has not guaranteed and has never guaranteed a set number of referrals to individual Job Network members. Job seekers, in fact, have been given choice under this government, not the compulsion under the previous government to attend the CES whether or not it delivered a job for them, a job interview or a job opportunity. We have given job seekers the choice to choose a job network that they want to go to. Under job matching, Job Network members are contracted to place people in jobs.

I am very pleased to be able to say that, of the 36 organisations at 107 sites in South Australia offering job matching services, 35 have made job placements as at 19 June. The one which has not made any placements yet—and what a pity that Senator Crowley and Senator Quirke are not here to hear this piece of truthful information—has, in fact, not commenced operations. While 35 organisations have made job placements, the one that has not has not yet started operations. So the next time that Senator Quirke and Senator Crowley pick up the Advertiser and read as gospel what appears in it, they may choose—as unfortunately the reporter did not—to check their facts with the minister's office. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator O'Chee and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, Senator O'Chee will withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in his name for the next day of sitting for the disallowance of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission Rules 1998, as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 1 and the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 332. I seek leave to have the committee's correspondence concerning these instruments incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—
The Hon Justice G M Giudice
President, Australian Industrial Relations Commission
Nauru House
80 Collins St
MELBOURNE VIC 3000
Dear President
I do not believe that the Committee has written directly to you before and therefore on behalf of the Committee I would like to congratulate you on your appointment as President of the Commission.

I am writing to you about the Australian Industrial Relations Commission Rules 1998, Statutory Rules 1998 No 1, about which the Committee has a number of concerns. The Committee has received and considered the letter of 17 April 1998 from the Industrial Registrar about these concerns and is most grateful to Mr Kelly, but we would appreciate your further advice.

The Committee's first concern relates to rule 6, which appears to be a subdelegation of legislative power by the Commission to itself, giving the Commission a putative power not provided for in the enabling Act. The Committee notes the advice from Mr Kelly that a similar provision has been in force since 1989 and that there is a similar provision in the Federal Court Rules, but this does not answer the question. Subdelegation of power such as that to make rules is void unless expressly authorised by the enabling Act and we would be grateful for your advice about the authority for rule 6.

By way of background I should say that the Committee detects numbers of delegated instruments which are void for subdelegation of power and that rule 6 is not unique. For instance, earlier this month, in reply to a query from the Committee, the Minister for Finance and Administration advised us that provisions in two separate Parts of a Remuneration Tribunal Determination would be amended in light of our concerns about the validity of subdelegations. With respect to the Federal Court Rules, the Committee will make further inquiries and if necessary write to the Chief Justice of that Court.

Our concerns about subrule 13(2) relate to the personal rights of those affected and to ensuring "best practice" in Commonwealth drafting. We note the advice from Mr Kelly that the subrule has not caused any prejudice and our concerns would be met by your confirmation that the procedures of the Commission are such that it is possible to ascertain the day on which the Registrar has failed (as distinct from refused) to make a decision or do an Act.

The Committee's final concern relates to the delay of 12 months between the making of the Practice Notes and the Rules, which appears to breach parliamentary propriety. The Minister for Workplace Relations has advised the Committee, in respect of another instrument, that it is a fundamental principle of administrative law that a public official entrusted by legislation with a discretionary power will normally be under a duty to exercise that power when appropriate circumstances arise. The Committee accepts this advice. In the opinion of the Committee that duty arose from 19 December 1996, the later date of assent of the two Acts which the Explanatory Statement advises are the basis of the Rules. The fact that the principal enabling legislation has been amended since then does not affect this duty. It is to be expected that enabling Acts will be amended from time to time. It is usual and accepted practice for delegated instruments which rely on particular enabling provisions to be made and to come into effect as soon as possible after those provisions.

The Committee has raised these concerns because industrial relations are an important and sensitive part of Australian public administration. Also, as you would know, the Committee has always been active in this area. For instance, the Acting Chief Justice and the Chief Justice of the Industrial Relations Court agreed to repeal and remake the entire Rules of that court (Statutory Rules 1994, No 110) in light of our concerns about prejudicial retrospectivity, apart from one provision which everyone appeared to agree could not be validly made in any case. The Committee also received assurances from the Chief Justice about two sets of Rules which become void because they were not tabled in Parliament within the required period.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
15 June 1998
Dear Senator,
Thank you for your letter of 25 May 1998 and for your kind congratulations. Please convey my thanks to the Committee also.

You refer to the Committee's concern that rule 6 of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission Rules 1998, Statutory Rules 1998 No.1, appears to be an impermissible sub-delegation of legislative power by the Commission. The Rules are made pursuant to s.48 of the Workplace Relations ACT 1996 (the Act). Section 48(1) reads:
48(1) The President, after consultation with members of the Commission, may, by signed instrument, make rules, not consistent smith this Acts with respect to:
(a) the practice and procedure to be followed in the Commission; or
(b) the conduct of business in the Commission: and, in particular:
(c) the manner in which, and the time within which. applications, submissions and objections may be made to the Commission; and
(d) the mariner in which applications, submissions and objections may be dealt with by the Commission.

The rules are intended to provide for the practice and procedure of the Commission and the conduct of its business subject to the important proviso that the rules must not be inconsistent with the Act. It is the Act which is therefore the primary legislative instrument and deals with substantive rights. This is not to deny that rights can be affected by the rules. In particular, a party which fails to comply with the rules faces the prospect of having their case dismissed. In those respects the Commission's rules are analogous to Rules of Court which almost universally contain a rule like rule 6. The ratio for such rules is that it may be grossly unfair to deprive a litigant of success because of a procedural noncompliance. Notoriously such non-compliance arises In relation to time limits on lodgement. A recent decision of The High Court is instructive as to the reasons why there should be a process to waive non-compliance with time limits contained in Rules of Court: Jackamarra v Vaguer (1998) 72 ALJR 819.

The power to waive compliance with procedural rules it may be argued, is particularly appropriate in light of the terms of ss. 98, 98A and 110(2)(c) of the Act. It may even be argued that absent a rule like rule 6 the rules as a whole might be "inconsistent with the Act." This is because it may be potentially unjust to require a party to comply with a procedural requirement. For example an applicant for an order under s.127(2) ought not be prejudiced by failure to serve a copy of the application on a party when the party is aware of the application through other means (rule 25(2)(c) refers).

I note from Hansard of 2 April 1998 your statement that rule 6 "May be an invalid sub-delegation of legislative power in that the Commission is allowing itself to make its own Rules (different from those tabled as Statutory Rules 1998 No.l) at any time that it chooses to do so." I am not sure that rule 6 has the characteristics which the Committee attributes to it. It confers a power to dispense with compliance. The discretion is not unbounded but must be exercised in accordance with the justice of the case: Hall v Nominal Defendant (1966) 117 CLR 423 at 429.

As the Industrial Registrar indicated in his letter to you of 17 April 1998, rule 6 finds its equivalent in the Rules of the Federal Court. It was not his intention to single out the Federal Court. There is an equivalent in the rules of most of the Australian Courts including the High Court: Order 64 Rule 2.

It is been said in relation to such rules that ". . . [R]ules must be the servant not the master of the Court": Clune v Watson (1882) Tarl 175 and "Rules and Forms of procedure are not ends in themselves, but a means to an end, which is the attainment of justice Coles v Ravenshaw [1907] 1 KB 1. Specifically, in respect of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the High Court has stated "[T]his Court, of course, recognises that the Commission is entitled to determine its own practice, consistently with the provisions of the law and the requirements of natural justice." Re Coldham and Others: Ex Parte The Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers' Federation (1985) 159 CLR 522 at 528.
In light of all of the above considerations there Is an overwhelming case for rule 6 or some similar rule.

In relation to subrule 13(2), I note that the Committee's concern would be met by confirmation that the procedures of the Commission are such that it is possible to ascertain the day on which a Registrar has failed (as distinct from refused) to make a decision or do an act. "Refusal" connotes a positive act whereas "failure" indicates the lack of one. The reference in the subrule to a failure provides a remedy for inaction of a kind which goes beyond a refusal. Of its nature a failure is usually a continuing state of affairs. Where the failure is of that kind, time never starts to run and an appeal may be brought at any time so long as the failure continues. Where the failure is constituted by the doing of an act, no doubt that act becomes the reference point for the calculation of the period within which the appeal must be made. (In such a case the relevant act may also constitute a refusal). I trust this explanation is satisfactory.

The Committee's final concern relates to the delay of 12 months between the making of the Practice Notes and the Rules which delay it is said appears to be a breach of parliamentary propriety Let me say at once tat the delay in finalising the rules was too long. It was brought about, however, by an unusual conjunction of circumstances which are unlikely to be repeated. The first of these matters was adverted to in the Industrial Registrar's letter namely the issue of a Practice Note in December 1996 to take the place of Interim Rules. In the absence of the practice direction there would have been no guidance for parties and their advisers in respect of numerous new provisions contained in the Act Perhaps the issue of the Practice Note engendered a false sense of security.

However that may be, there then followed a consultation process with members of the Commission, as required by s.48, and with some of the major industrial parties. It was difficult to undertake these consultations earlier in light of the extremely short time frame between the assent and commencement of the legislation.

You will be aware that my predecessor resigned her position in July 1997. I was appointed on 17 September 1997. Although the question of finalising the rules was brought to my attention within the first few weeks I was not prepared to make the rules without satisfying myself that they hat been considered adequately and would not require substantial amendment in the near future. In the event at least one change was made in the draft which hat been prepared by the Office of Legislative Drafting in July 1997. Further amendments were made to the Act towards the end of the year and it seemed sensible to wait then so that the new rules could be comprehensive.

The Minister for Workplace Relations has given the Committee advice which has led the Committee to form the opinion that the President of the Commission was under a duty to make rules and that duty arose on 19 December 1996. I have not been furnished with the advice. The principles to be applied in ascertaining whether a statutory power of this kind must be exercised are set out in a well known passage in the joint judgment of the High Court in Ward v Williams (1955) 92 CLR 496 at 505-6. Reference is often made also to dicta of Windeyer J in Finance Facilities Pty Ltd v Royal Insurance Australia Ltd (1994) 182 CLR 51 at 64, 84-5 and 97. The principles may be summarised as follows. The use of the "may" in a statute is prima facie facultative, but the particular provision, the statutory context or the general scope and the objects of the statute may indicate that the person to whom the power is given is bound to exercise it if specified conditions are fulfilled. Although I am open to argument to the contrary, it seems to me that s.48(1) is not mandatory but permissive

As I have already noted, I have not seen the advice referred to. It may be that the advice raises some consideration of which I am not aware. As presently advised, however, there is nothing apparent which requires "may" in s.48 to be read as "must". In the final analysis this may be a sterile debate since I agree that it is desirable that there be rules and that the delay in their making was inordinate.
Should you wish to discuss any of these matters further please contact the Industrial Registrar, Mr M Kelly who will make the arrangements.
Yours faithfully
Justice Giudice
President
5 March 1998
The Hon Dr Michael Wooldridge MP
Minister for Health and Family Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 332, which make changes to the Principal Regulations consequent upon the enactment of the Hearing Services Administration Act 1997 and the Hearing Services and AHS Reform Act 1997 .

New subregulation 3H(3) of the Principal Regulations permits the Health Insurance Commission to disclose to the Department of Health and Family Services a wide range of information about claims and payments relating to hearing services. Although this provision is authorised by the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 , the Committee would appreciate your advice as to whether the Privacy Commissioner was consulted on the content of this subregulation.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator W.G. O'Chee
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Bill

Thank you for you for your letter of 5 March 1998 concerning the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 332. You asked whether the Privacy Commission was consulted on the content of subregulation 3H(3). I apologise for the delay in responding.

Consultation was not undertaken with the Privacy Commissioner prior to making the new regulation as there was a pre-existing regulation. That regulation, which was not disallowed. provided for disclosure of information, including personal information, to the entity responsible for oversight of hearing services (at that time, Australian Hearing Services).
The new regulation replicates that arrangement, but updates it to reflect recent changes in the delivery of hearing services, namely:
(a) the relocation of the administration and management of the hearing services program into the Office of Hearing Services, with the Department of Health and Family Services; and
(b) the somewhat broader information needs generated by the new structure, which is in accordance with the wishes of Parliament as set out in the Hearing Services and Administration Act 1997.

The role of the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) is to pay claims while the Department of Health and Family Services is responsible for administering the hearing services program As the Department is the formal recipient of personal information (a matter which is made clear to hearing services clients; see attached form), the HIC considered that no new privacy issues or other matters affecting the personal rights or liberties of hearing services clients were raised by the new regulation.
With kind regards,
Yours sincerely
Dr Michael Wooldridge

subdebateinfo.title: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)—by leave—proposed:
That:
(a) The hours of meeting for today shall be 2.00 p.m.—6.30 p.m. and 7.30 p.m.—11.10 p.m.
(b) The routine of business from 7.30 p.m. till 10.30 p.m. shall be government business only.
(c) The question for the adjournment of the Senate shall be proposed at 10.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will support the motion that has been proposed by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ian Campbell), although I want to indicate that the opposition does have a number of concerns with the way the program is currently being managed. Senator Ian Campbell, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, has provided the opposition, the minor parties and Independent senators with a list of legislation. That list is broken up into priority legislation, which is described as legislation the government intends to deal with prior to rising at the end of these sittings, and non-controversial legislation, which is a very substantial list indeed.

speech.para: The Manager of Government Business in the Senate provides an indicative estimation of time for debate on the so-called winter list, which is the priority list of legislation. I want to make the point that it has proved impossible in the past to make an accurate prediction about the amount of time that is needed to debate legislation. I suspect the best example we have is the recent case of the Managed Investments Bill 1997 , which is one bill that even Senator Ian Campbell himself has been handling for the government in the chamber. I think his own estimate has been out by something like a factor of four for the debate on that bill.

I want to also indicate—and I do not know the views of the minor parties or Independents on this matter—that there are some bills on the list of priority legislation that, as far as the opposition is concerned, we do not intend to grant an exemption from the cut off. Obviously, if a majority of the Senate were of a like mind to the opposition on this matter, then clearly those bills would not be available for debate in the Senate during this session.

I have indicated that there is a very substantial list of non-controversial legislation. Non-controversial legislation tends to be matters on which there is at best a very short committee stage and no divisions required during the second reading stage or committee consideration of these bills. Really what `non-controversial' means is no divisions and no objections from senators. As I read the list of proposed non-controversial legislation, I see a significant number of bills that I am aware involve amendments and, therefore, may not be accepted by all in the chamber as being non-controversial. I assume this is something the Manager of Government Business has taken into account.

On a more substantive and immediate issue, I am concerned that the list of legislation that has been provided to the opposition by the government does not indicate a proposed order of consideration for legislation. I do think that is a very significant issue. Apart from the guidance we have on the Senate red, the Senate Order of Business, we have no guidance from the government in relation to a proposed order of consideration of those bills. In that respect, I imagine that the majority of senators in the chamber would consider that this is not a program; it is characterised more as a wish list from the government.

If the government expects cooperation on the matter we are debating now, which goes to the Senate sitting this evening, Tuesday evening—and we have heard the manager a moment ago give a notice of a motion for the Senate to sit on Thursday evening of this week and Friday of this week—then it could at least provide us with a program for the final week and a half of sittings. Frankly, I have to say that I cannot recall an occasion when we have been two days into a two-week sitting period when that two-week legislative program has not been provided to the Senate. I think that situation is virtually without precedent.

Given the motion that we have before us at the moment and given the situation that we have a motion to give consideration to tomorrow in relation to sitting on Thursday night and Friday, which I think the opposition would be mindful to support on the understanding that we have some indication from the government of what is proposed in the program, what is missing is that we do not have a legislative program before the Senate. We have got two wish lists, but we do not have an order of consideration and we have no program at all for the final week of this two-week sitting period. That is, I think, absolutely unacceptable.

I ask that the Manager of Government Business indicate when we might expect that program to be made available for the benefit of senators. I do not think that is an unreason able request. I also think that the Senate is entitled to hear what the manager has in mind in relation to any prospective extra sitting periods, be it the Senate sitting in further evening sessions next week, be it the Senate sitting an extra day on Friday next week or the like.

I also make this point, and I think this is a substantive point: I notice that the Native Title Amendment Bill is absent from both the list of priority legislation and the list of so-called controversial legislation. It does not appear on either list that Senator Ian Campbell has provided the Senate.

talk.start.para: —It is in their minds, perhaps?
—No, I assume we take it from the absence—
—John, if you want to vote, I will put it now.

—I think you understand what our position is on this, but you are the manager. What I am putting forward here are, I think, some reasonable concerns about the program in response to a motion—that the opposition intends to vote for—in relation to extra sittings tonight. I make the substantive point to the Manager of Government Business that the Native Title Amendment Bill is not on the prospective legislative program. We can probably only take from the fact that the Native Title Amendment Bill does not appear that the government does not intend bringing the bill back to the Senate during these sittings. I am sure these are issues of concern to all senators.

speech.para: I appreciate the fact that there is a plan to hold a discussion amongst all parties and Independent senators in the chamber to try to work through some of the issues. But, before some of these matters are given any further consideration, I think that the Senate is entitled to some answers to some of those concerns which, with due respect to all concerned, are matters of substance. It is not unreasonable that, before this matter is voted on, and even though I have given an indication of the opposition's intentions in relation to the motion before us, we know what the government's response is.

I do make the point, particularly in relation to the programming, that it is absolutely unheard of for us to get to this point—the second day of what was planned as an eight-day sitting fortnight; now there is a proposal from the government that it be a nine-day sitting—

talk.start.para: —Probably 10.

—Possibly 10, but that is a matter for further consideration. We would obviously appreciate the government letting us know what they have in mind. But it is, I think, unheard of at this point in the sittings, given the program we have got in front of us, for us not to have an idea about the planning of the government in relation to when this legislation is to come before the chamber. I think the chamber is entitled to some indication from the government at this point as to what the proposed order of consideration of bills might be.

speech.para: As I have indicated, the opposition will support this motion. I have made clear to the Leader of the Government in the Senate that, if we are to sit tonight, we may as well make it a meaningful sitting of the Senate. The suggestion that we have a situation of no quorums and no divisions—a situation in which, one assumes, only a couple of opposition senators would make speeches and perhaps many government senators would not front up—is not acceptable. If we are to sit the extra time, we ought to work for the extra period of time. I gather that view of the program has been accepted by the government.

If the program is as substantial as we hear from the government, then I do not really think that we can afford to waste the time of the Senate if there is agreement to allow the Senate to sit extra hours. I would ask that, at the conclusion of this debate, the manager respond to the substantive issues that I have raised in my contribution.

talk.start.para: —I oppose the motion. We are not at the end of a parliamentary period; we are three years into a three-year parliamentary period. An election so far as this parliament is concerned is due about May next year. This whole motion is based on the unspoken presumption that there will be an election in August. The presumption is that the government wants to get through as much legislation as it can in this fortnight in preparation for that election, not least legislation for the sale of the rest of Telstra so that the government can be out on the hustings saying that it is going to spend money out of that sale to magically defend the interests of the bush and ordinary consumers as far as telecommunications are concerned. But it does not want to say when or how or why that election is going to take place.

speech.para: There is no justification for this situation arising in the Senate at this time. As far as Telstra and many of the other pieces of legislation are concerned, we should be dealing with them in the winter session when we come back here after 5 August. The whole rush to have us sit tonight, Thursday night and Friday, the same next week and potentially a week after that is to suit the government's electoral purposes.

If the government says that we are going to have an election in August, then we have something fixed in our minds that we can debate. But with things—not including native title—up in the air, the government does not know what it is doing about an election. What we are seeing in here is really part of the chaotic situation that the government is in at the moment over its election planning.

Not only has the Prime Minister to deal with the National Party that does not want to go to an election all of a sudden, and many members of government who are getting very nervous about the prospects of an August election, but the Manager of Government in the Senate—and I feel sorry for him—has ministers wanting to get their legislation through before an election comes up, just in case. It will take a long while to get it through if the government wins afterwards.

talk.start.para: —Some of them have been waiting for two years to get some of these bills through.
—If they have been waiting for two years to get these bills through, there is something wrong with the way the government has been prioritising that legislation.
—Eighty-five hours of native title is a pretty fair review of that legislation.

—The government has the opportunity in an orderly fashion to make sure that their sitting times enable it to get its legislation properly debated. I am not cavelling over that, and I am not cavelling over the amount of time that the honourable manager talks about which has been given to native title, which has twice been brought before this place, and, goodness knows, may well be brought before it again if Senator Harradine caves in in the next week or two. That is not the point.

speech.para: What I am saying is that the government is in a chaotic position and, unfortunately, the manager is at the centre of that trying to get some order out of it. But ministers are coming from everywhere saying to the manager, `We want to get our piece of legislation through.' Suddenly this is urgent; suddenly they want to appear like they have been able to progress on matters that are important to the electorate as we go to an election over winter.

I say again that this country should not be going to an election now. The country should be going to an election next year. If ever there was an argument for fixed term elections, this is it; if ever there was an argument for legislation to be introduced in here to say that elections should be every third year on a specified date and the government cannot alter that, then this is it.

I am happy to stay here tonight. I came in at 8 o'clock yesterday and I left just after midnight last night, even though the Senate was not sitting, because there are really important electoral matters that I am dealing with. If we sit tonight, it will simply eat into that time, but it will not make any difference what time I go to bed. As the Leader of the Opposition says, the government has not come forward with an orderly program. It does not have a program fixed for the next two days, let alone the next week.

I note that we have not had the necessary motions passed for the electoral reform that the government has in mind, which, by the way, if the government's aims are fulfilled, would deprive 15,000 prisoners in this coun try of their vote in legislation hurried through here in the next ten days. This is again trying to advantage the government as it heads towards the ballot box. They will be getting some curry from me over that one if it appears on the schedule in the next fortnight. For those reasons, I oppose this motion.

talk.start.para: —I would like to put on the record that, as usual, the Democrats are terribly reasonable and we will not be opposing this motion. However, we really see absolutely no reason whatsoever why most of these bills cannot be dealt with in the next session. We see no reason whatsoever why we should not be coming back for a next session, or are we coming back for a next session? We do not know.

speech.para: Obviously, appropriations bills are urgent and we would expect them to be dealt with expeditiously. I look forward to the leaders and whips meeting tomorrow when I am sure we will get a list of what the government is expecting over the next two weeks and the time frame they are expecting it in. We will not be voting against the motion, but we certainly see no urgency in most of these bills.

talk.start.para: —I would like to respond mostly to the points that Senator Faulkner raised because they were serious points. Senator Brown's point that this is all determined because of some secret election agenda is not the case. I suspect that we have had all of these bills on the Notice Paper and on the government's legislative program since we came back here at the beginning of these sittings and we are seeking to deal with them.

speech.para: On the substantive point about the native title legislation, there has been speculation about whether native title will come back in here. I understand from reading the paper that Senator Harradine has suggested to the Prime Minister in a phone call that he would like to discuss some amendments. Clearly, from reading the paper—and I have not actually read the papers yet this morning, or at least anything about that—those discussions are either continuing or whatever. But I certainly as manager have not been told, `Ian, please get ready because we are going to bring native title back in.'

I am managing the program based on what I know, and that is that we have a list of legislation which, as I recall, is pretty much in the same state it was in when we came here a few weeks ago. Senator Faulkner suggested that the Managed Investments Bill had taken a lot longer than I estimated. As he knows, for the past 18 months I have been seeking very unsuccessfully to estimate how long it takes to debate legislation in this place. Some bits of legislation go through very quickly. But most take much longer than my estimations and I misjudged the Managed Investments Bill very badly.

I had held very constructive discussions with the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats in relation to their amendments and we had a very clear view as to where the party stood on that legislation. We could have passed it in that time, but Senator Margetts—as is her right—came into this place yesterday and produced a comprehensive set of amendments which needed to be debated in some detail.

The Greens (WA) did not take up my offer of briefings and discussions and information offerings in relation to those bills. But, again, that is their right. They do not need to talk to me if they do not want to, and it is their right to come in here and move those things. I estimated that it would take that time and Senator Faulkner is quite right: I was about 400 per cent out, and I suspect, by the end of the debate, about 500 per cent or 600 per cent out. It is about equivalent to my record in backing the horses, so I might give up estimating time.

talk.start.para: —Just give up as manager of government business.

—Just give up? Right. The other important point that Senator Faulkner raised was this issue of the program. We provided to all leaders and whips, if not all senators, a program for this week which included nine of the 14 bills on our priority list. In other words, we set out a program which included those bills and the order in which we wanted them debated this week. That leaves four or five bills on the priority list that we would seek to deal with in week 2.

speech.para: We are here for a two-week program. We have scheduled, in the priority order that existed on Wednesday, 10 June—and that is when we circulated the list—a program for all of this week with the order for the nine pieces of legislation, so that leaves five pieces of legislation for week 2. As Senator Faulkner correctly points out, some of those bills have not been exempted from the cut-off and the government may not be able to deal with them. So you have a priority order and a program with the exclusion of no more than five bills. You knew the order on 10 June. It is 13 days ago that you were given that order and that program. It has been the practice of this government to send the program out for the coming sitting week a week to 10 days ahead of each sitting week. In the fortnight we send out the program for the coming week on the Friday, and of course we have regular discussions with other parties.

talk.start.para: —The Labor government, which you were so critical of, put out a program a fortnight in advance.

—The Australian Labor Party, as Senator Faulkner says in his private conversation across the chamber, sent out on occasions, or regularly perhaps, two-week indicative programs. Of course, Senator Faulkner had the same problem that I have—that the government's priorities change. They used to change and reorder their priorities very regularly. Senator Faulkner did raise the issue of the Native Title Bill in 1993, which, he will recall—I am not sure whether he was the manager at the time—
—He was the manager.
—He was the manager—
—In the good old days when we had a really good manager!
—In those days! He will recall that at the end of those sittings in December 1993 the Native Title Bill, which I am sure he would not have estimated was going to take two or three hours—
—The only thing that I didn't take into account was your disruptive behaviour!
—We gave that bill detailed consideration. We thought we gave it detailed consideration. It may have been too lengthy.
—You filibustered!
—Some people would call it a filibuster, but even in the detailed consideration that we gave that bill in 1993—I think that debate was about 52 hours—
—You cannot claim there was filibustering in this one.
—Of course there was not, Senator Margetts, and that is exactly what I said in 1993 when I was sitting on that side of the chamber.
—You were wrong then.

—I know: I am always wrong and you are always right, and one day I will see the light. Hallelujah! But there was detailed scrutiny that the then opposition gave the native title legislation that Senator Faulkner introduced on the last afternoon of the scheduled sittings. I think we were due to rise that evening and at 5 o'clock or thereabouts—you can go back and check the Hansard— the native title legislation was brought in. That was an example of the sort of program we had to deal with in those days. I know as well as Senator Faulkner that trying to manage government programs in a Senate where you do not have the numbers is difficult. But it is worth comparing the scrutiny that the Native Title Bill got in 1993 with the 85 hours that the Senate gave it scrutiny for in the last 12 months. In fact, the 50 hours that the Senate spent on native title in 1993 were all additional hours. They were all added to the program; they were additional weeks. Some of us will remember sitting on a Saturday and sitting many, many extra days on top of the government's program. All agreements, as I recall—and I recall reading the Hansard recently on this matter—that were made with the opposition at that time were breached, as I understand. That was a matter between Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner at the time.
—You breached them!

—It is reported in the Hansard . The people who are interested in this debate can debate that. It was debated in 1993. That debate took 50 hours of additional time. The native title debate over the past 12 months has taken 85 hours. Every senator in this place who wants to be honest and up-front about it knows that that is one of the reasons why the government has a backlog of 100 pieces of legislation. Some of that legislation, such as migration laws which affect the rights and responsibilities of migrants and other citizens, has been sitting on the Notice Paper for many months. One of the reasons we have a backlog of about 100 pieces of legislation is because the Senate chose to spend 85 hours debating native title and 52 hours debating industrial relations laws. Of course, we had to re-present those bills. So we are in this situation where there is a backlog of important legislation and we are seeking to deal with it in a well-managed way in a place where we do not have majority support.

speech.para: I say, in response to Senator Faulkner's points, you have a program in front of you. The government is seeking to give absolute clarity to all parties as to what we are dealing with and in what order. No-one can complain about that. We accommodate on a very regular, if not a daily, basis members of the opposition and opposition frontbenchers coming to us—I do not know whether they do it through Senator Faulkner or with Senator Faulkner's support—and saying `Look, sorry, we can't deal with this particular measure today because I have have to go somewhere.'

talk.start.para: —You keep changing the program.
—No, we do not.
—Yes, you do.

—We have a program. I will get down to specifics then, Senator Faulkner. A shadow minister says, `Sorry, I have to move house today so let's not do the social security bill.' Another shadow minister says, `I have to go and see some people in Adelaide so let's not do this bill.' So we rearrange the program on a daily basis to accommodate opposition shadow ministers very regularly, and we stick to it as much as we can. That is how we are dealing with the program. We try to accommodate Democrat senators and Green senators when they say, `It would be really helpful if we could do this.' So we rearrange our program. We try to accommodate senators as much as we can.
—This has got absolutely nothing to do with the issue before the chair.

—The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate asked me to respond to his substantive points. One of them was that we do not have a program. Senator Faulkner perhaps does not know that he was sent a copy of a program that covers 90 per cent of the government's legislative program.
—It covers one week.
—It covers 90 per cent of the program.
—It covers one week.

—It covers nine bills out of 14 bills. They are placed into an order, and Senator Faulkner wants to pretend that he has not received a program. He has received a program, and he has received a priority order for nine out of 14 bills. What you can assess from that, Senator Faulkner, is that the government gives priority to the nine bills that are on the program for this week and they lower the priority for the five bills that remain. We want to deal with nine bills this week and five next week. That is our priority; that is our program. Senator Faulkner has the program. Senator Brown has the program. All senators have seen that program. I think it is available even on the Internet. Sorry, it is not available on the Internet.
—You don't know whether it is on the Internet or not.

—I have just been told that it is not on the Internet. I do not even know how to get into the Internet, but I know that Senator Schacht knows. So I will give him a copy of the program and he can stick it on his home page.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition

talk.start.para: —The President has received a letter from Senator Stott Despoja proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interjection.para: The Government's decision to defund the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition (AYPAC), the peak national youth affairs organisation in the community sector.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

—I rise today to discuss this matter of public importance relating to the government's decision to defund Australia's national peak youth representative body, the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, AYPAC. The Australian Democrats condemn this decision; we condemn not only the decision to defund the organisation but the political move behind the government's move to shut down the only national peak representative body of this kind in Australia today.

speech.para: There has been a peak national body for young people in this country for 20 years. Although AYPAC was established in 1991 and has been in existence ever since, this country has had such an umbrella peak youth organisation since the inception of the youth affairs councils of Australia in 1979. So ever since the establishment of AYPAC and its predecessor organisations, governments have been able to work with such bodies—until now. This government has chosen not to work with this organisation; it has chosen to close it down and, instead, to meet only twice a year with a select group of young Australians.

Last Thursday Dr David Kemp, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, gave, I believe, 20 minutes notice to AYPAC that it was about to lose its funding as at 30 June this year. So that organisation has been given less than a fortnight's notice of being expected to disband and halt its activities. The notice he gave them was that their contract would not be renewed.

I have to contemplate this decision with some cynicism, given that AYPAC will stop operating from 30 June—the end of this financial year—and we will see the commencement the next day of the government's new youth payments system, the common youth allowance. So it is incredibly coincidental that the day the common youth allowance is due to commence AYPAC—an organisation which provides important research and policy advice to government as well as advocating on behalf of young people and representing their views not only to governments but to the community generally, to non-government organisations, et cetera—will be no longer in existence.

So I have to ask: how bad does the government think its common youth allowance is going to be? It has effectively disbanded the one body that not only could give it advice on how to improve difficulties and nasties in that system but would be out there advocating—it is one of many bodies, but certainly the only peak national representative body of young people—on behalf of young people who find themselves faced with problems through the introduction of the common youth allowance on 1 July this year. So the timing is incredibly suspicious. But it is a blatant political decision by this government: it is a decision to silence the voice of young people—in particular, to silence the youth sector in this nation. As I say, it is very, very timely indeed.

AYPAC represents a number of groups. I will list only a couple. I could go on all afternoon, but I will not take up the Senate's time because many of these names were put on record by me last night in the adjournment debate. That list includes Girl Guides, YMCA, YWCA, St Vincent de Paul, National Union of Students, Australian Association of Adolescent Health, Australian Rural Youth, as well as the state and territory youth affairs peak bodies. These groups will now be denied a permanent, ongoing, year-round representative body in the form of AYPAC.

It is clear what some of these groups think of the decision, Madam Deputy President. You just have to look at some of the press release headlines that have come out since the decision was announced. One is from the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission—hardly a subversive group in our society: `Government drops youth affairs in too-hard basket'. That commission recognises that this decision is a political one designed to, effectively, ban dissent and silence young people's voices. The Catholic Commission for Justice, Development and Peace has said `Silencing the messenger—another advocacy group bites the dust'. The media release of the Catholic Social Services has the headline `Youth to lose voice—loss of quality research and advocacy'. Centrecare Sydney's media release reads `Federal coalition unwilling to listen to youth'. How true that is.

So, instead of an expert, well-resourced, permanent youth policy body, the government has decided that the only input it wants from young people, and the only input that it will accept, is through a twice-yearly meeting of 50 young people—so that is twice a year with a select few. There is no indication that these young people will be given the resources they need in order to adequately develop policy and advice to government and to liaise with other organisations on behalf of young people.

Again, this is another promise broken; it is another so-called non-promise from this government. I quote from the government's federal election strategy for young people, the youth policy `Giving hope to our young', which was released in 1996. It said that the Howard government would `improve the effectiveness of government in responding to the needs and concerns of young Australians by consulting directly with young Australians around the nation through formal representative organisations such as AYPAC.'

AYPAC has been an invaluable resource not only in the provision of policy advice to successive governments but also in assisting those who work with young people providing information through newsletters, conferences, publications, national forums and a range of mechanisms. In fact, most recently it was working through DEETYA's youth offices in order to assist youth affairs networks with the coordination of those 41 new youth offices. This is exactly the kind of liaison between government and non-government organisations that AYPAC has been effectively providing for many years. Of course, its national conferences, the youth gatherings—certainly in 1994 and 1996—are examples of providing opportunities for young people to have a say in government.

Yesterday, when I asked the minister representing the minister, Senator Ellison, about this issue, he seemed to think an Internet site would be appropriate. He seemed to think that would somehow suffice, along with these round table meetings, as a way for young people—

talk.start.para: —What's wrong with having an Internet site?

—I take that interjection. How many homeless young people have access to the Internet, Senator Tierney? How many young people would prefer face-to-face contact with a youth sector representative, with a government official or with a spokesperson from DEETYA, rather than tapping online? I am not suggesting that an Internet site is a bad thing, that a round table is a bad thing in itself or that additional assistance to the YMCA youth forums is a bad thing; I am saying that the government could have taken the opportunity to complement the existing structure of AYPAC, not to defund youth representation in this country by at least another $140,000. There has been a drop in funding; don't think the replacement organisations or policies or round tables will be given the same resources that AYPAC had—indeed, they will not. As for the idea that some kind of chat line with Dr Kemp through the Internet will be appropriate—it will not be. (Time expired)

—What a storm in a teacup this is. If we have a look at what the minister has done—and his decision is not to renew the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition contract—AYPAC has not been defunded, as Senator Stott Despoja claimed in the adjournment last night and again just now. Instead, the government has chosen not to renew its contract.
—A huge difference.

—We do these sorts of things all the time, and the last government certainly did this sort of thing all the time with all sorts of bodies. It would give something funding for three years and then not fund that and fund other things. Senator Stott Despoja is trying to make out that there is absolutely nothing in its place. I want to spend my time today pointing out what the government has put in place instead of this particular organisation and also what this government has done for youth in its policies, in youth support, in education and other things.

speech.para: Even though Senator Stott Despoja might try to rubbish the idea of having an Internet site, it has been highly successful, which I will demonstrate in a minute. The government's plan has provided alternative ways for the youth of this nation to share their voice with the government, and it is part of the ongoing commitment of this government to the youth of the country. We do have a federal youth affairs ministry in this country, something which we did not have under the previous government. Indeed, the state government of New South Wales had a youth affairs ministry under the Liberal government, and the Labor government abolished that particular body—so much for what the ALP thinks about the youth of the country.

In addition to this, we have established a round table—the round table much maligned by Senator Stott Despoja—but this will be far more representative than the original system set up by Labor. It will represent youth from all walks of life. Pay attention, Senator, and concentrate on the fact that the previous organisation had a peak group of five to make the representations, whereas we will have a round table of 50 which will be much more representative and much broader in its advice to government. In addition to this, DEETYA is setting up a youth bureau which will complement this and which will consult directly with peak bodies on youth matters across Australia. Designated officers will maintain relationships so that the voice of those peak bodies does come through to the minister.

In addition, if I can turn to the Internet site, which was much maligned by Senator Stott Despoja claiming that youth had no access at all—that is how much in the Dark Ages Senator Stott Despoja is—14,000 hits a week. I think that is not too bad as a supplementary thing; this is not a replacement. There have been 14,000 hits on this site and this is just starting. This is not a bad thing. You are trying to make out that all youth do not have such a site in their home, that is quite right, but there is quite a lot of access to such sites through public libraries, through universities, through schools and Internet cafes or wherever. Senator Stott Despoja yesterday accused the government of being afraid of meeting young people, and I think the initiatives I have outlined and the way in which we have set this up as an alternative structure—

talk.start.para: —What about the Young Liberals?

—We do not have to follow Labor Party ideas. The Labor Party set up all sorts of structures, we do not necessarily have to follow them, particularly if there is a better way, a more broadly representative way, if there is a way of using new technology to do this.

speech.para: Consultation is one thing, action is another. This government has introduced a number of programs which have been extremely helpful to youth and which are very popular with youth out in the community. If we look at the development of programs such as work for the dole, Green Corps, and the 220,000 new apprentices that will be starting between 1997 and 1999, we will see that people are appreciative of them. Unlike the previous government's so-called Working Nation program that put them on a treadmill where they just had training and no work, these people are actually out there working and getting work experience which does set them up in a much better way for work in the future. Of course, the work will be there in much greater quantities than it was under the last Labor government.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, who is interjecting all the time, why don't you interject and tell us about net job creation under your government between 1990 and 1994? How many net new jobs did you create in four years? We created more than that in the last three months. You had such a massive recession, such a massive loss of jobs to youth over 1990-1994, that it has taken years to recover from your programs and the way in which you mismanaged the economy over 13 years. Under this government, with the creation of budget surpluses, getting the economy back on track with lower inflation, with us getting off the back of small business, we are actually creating real jobs for the youth instead of that job treadmill that you had.

speech.para: As well as having a better opportunity for jobs, if they do need income support from the government, the youth of this country have a much better arrangement than they did under your government. We had a major inquiry in the Senate which pointed out the shortcomings of your Austudy system. With the common youth allowance, that Senator Stott Despoja was maligning a little bit earlier, we are actually putting more resources into this, we are paying more money into this than your previous government, and students who were under the old Austudy system now have access to things like living away from home allowances as well as getting more money.

It was not a coincidence, as Senator Stott Despoja was trying to make out, that the change in the arrangement for consulting youth happened at the same time as the common youth allowance. It had nothing to do with it at all. We are keeping mechanisms in place for consultations with youth. We are undertaking programs which actually help youth get a job and we are creating the economic conditions so that when they have been through experiences like work for the dole and Green Corps out there in the private sector, under the policies of this government, they have got a much better chance of getting lasting, sustained work.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Stott Despoja. This government have pursued one agenda above all others, and that is to silence their critics. Whether it is the ABC, women's organisations or ATSIC, anyone who they perceive as being critical of their policies and their way of doing business gets the chop. Now they have gone after Australia's youth. The decision to cut funding—or, in Senator Tierney's words, not to renew the contract—of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition brings to the fore this government's petty, small-minded prejudice towards politically active Australians in general, and in this case young people in particular.

speech.para: AYPAC cannot be stereotyped as a left-wing lobby group. In fact, AYPAC represents 22 youth organisations, many of which are non-political and can even be described as conservative in their nature. AYPAC is a peak representative body. It brings together the structural organisation of many youth representative bodies in an organised way. AYPAC does this on the basis that there is a critical need for national youth organisations to coordinate their information sharing. Why? Because it is efficient to do so. This is where some of the ironies to do with this government come into play. They talk about efficiencies in dissemination of information and how to get people involved, yet at the same time they actively undermine and de-fund those structures which are designed to assist them in getting their message out and in extracting from the community its points of view and expressions of interest in various matters.

We must not forget that AYPAC includes 300 associate members that represent local youth networks and individuals, and it is these networks that rely so heavily on the infrastructure that AYPAC provides. This infrastructure is very practical. It is about circulating information on legislation before this place and before the parliaments of the states and Territories and about issues of importance to young people confronting local govern ments right around of the country. To have a central point where information can be circulated in this way is absolutely critical for the young people of Australia to feel as though they are actively connected to our political processes. In trying to silence AYPAC, the government is marginalising the voices of thousands of young Australians across a wide spectrum of the population.

This is in the context of a much broader political attack on young people. Let us have a look at it. The introduction of the common youth allowance has already been mentioned by previous speakers. That is coming up shortly. Experience shows us that, whether it is the Austudy debacle or whether it is what we have seen with Centrelink just in the last two weeks, this government has a very bad history of mismanaging new systems. What better way to smooth the path for a controversial new allowance than to disenfranchise the voice of those who are there waiting and watching and who will act as a watchdog on the implementation of those new policies?

We have seen changes with respect to industrial relations. AYPAC has taken a very active role in monitoring the status of young people with respect to the industrial relations system and awards. We know that the government's 20 allowable matters will marginalise young people's ability to stand up for themselves in our industrial relations system. We know that young people are not highly unionised and do not have the protection that a union can offer in terms of an award and sticking up for their rights in the workplace.

These attacks keep coming. I have already mentioned Austudy. In higher education there have been a billion dollars worth of cuts, cutting off the opportunity for so many young Australians to participate in higher education and thereby better themselves and be able to seek work in an area contingent upon having those qualifications.

But this attack is not just limited to higher education. We have seen a transfer in government support from the public education system to the private education system, favouring those in our society who have some advantage already. All these things tell the young people of Australia one thing: that this government has absolutely no interest in representing them or their concerns.

AYPAC's value to our political system is absolutely imperative. Its role is to coordinate responses to matters relevant to young people and to promote the needs of young Australians. It is a mechanism to identify the needs of young Australians and to convey those needs cohesively to the respective governments so that, hopefully, government can respond. Not only does AYPAC inform government about the needs of young Australians but it also serves to inform its members. As I said before, it is a resource, and the sad irony is that this government is actively disenfranchising a resource that I think it will come to find it will sorely miss.

I would now like to turn to the alternative that the government has offered in the context of this particular event. In terminating AYPAC's funding, the minister has offered a youth round table. It is an interesting concept: they did the same thing when they defunded a plethora of women's organisations. Instead of using the networks that have evolved and existed within the communities of these people, they have chosen to restructure in a way that suits them. Such a round table—if it is indeed there to serve the purpose of providing a direct voice to the minister—should serve as a supplement to AYPAC. It should be additional, and perhaps it would be a worthy addition, but it certainly is not worthy as a replacement.

The minister reckons that sitting down twice a year with a select group of hand-picked young Australians is all he needs in terms of policy input. Is there no end to this government's arrogance? Every member of AYPAC, which includes the organisations I alluded to earlier, has come out actively supporting continued funding for this peak youth body. Unfortunately, Minister Kemp is offering young people nothing more than plain old tokenism.

If you want an example of how this Tory tokenism to youth affairs will work, you only need to look at the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory youth advisory body has only one indigenous person on it, yet indigen ous Australians make up about 30 per cent of the population. This government is living so far in the past with its attitudes to community involvement in policy-making and accessing appropriate networks and voices in the community that it serves only to reinforce the perception that John Howard so rigidly gives when he stands up and talks about Australia as though we were living in the 1950s.

What is Minister Kemp actually offering young Australians? It is not a commitment to act on their concerns, because that commitment was made before the last election. We now know the difference between a Howard commitment and a real commitment. Obviously this government's commitment to Australia's young people was not a core promise. It was a non-core promise—one that has been completely expendable. It seems that the minister would rather be seen in a pair of jeans, eating pizza with a select group of young Libs networking their way through life than to actually deal with the realities of working with an organisation that offers some intellectual in-depth analysis of policy and legislation.

It is easy for us on this side of the chamber to actively oppose the policies of this government and to identify the issues of deficiency in what they espouse and for them to criticise us enough for us to debate the issues. It is another matter altogether to completely take away the voice of a peak representative youth body that has established itself with great credibility and great dignity across governments of all persuasions.

This government has shown what it thinks about the needs of young Australians. By removing AYPAC they are saying that Australia's youth are not worthy of proper representation. They are discouraging young Australians from being politically active and from taking an active role in the considerations in this place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the defunding of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition with a sense of despair at the demise of substantive democracy in Australia. For the information of senators opposite, substantive democracy is that in which all groups in society are offered the opportunity to participate in the political arena. This is not to say that participation will be equal. Kerry Packer will always have a greater influence on public policy than tens of thousands of Australian youth, but it is a recognition that systems must be put in place for sections of the community to autonomously organise and agitate for positive change. The defunding of AYPAC and its replacement with a round table of youth elite, hand-picked by the department, is a gross attack on substantive democracy for young Australians. It is a transparent attempt to silence legitimate dissent against an arrogant and patronising government.

speech.para: Let us look at this youth round table for a moment. It is going to meet twice a year to discuss government policy, and it will be funded to cover air fares and accommodation. Where is the capacity for this group to critically analyse government policy? Where is the capacity for this group to have the organisational and information resources to challenge departmental officials and ministers? Could it be that they do not want this to happen? It is difficult enough for senators in this place, with all our access to resources, to extract information from ministers and their departments. What hope do these young people, who lob into Canberra twice a year, have to play anything but a token role? But that is what the government is all about with this decision: silencing dissent.

AYPAC have provided an invaluable service to the community in commenting on matters such as the youth allowance. For their honesty, hard work and commitment to young Australians, they have copped it in the neck from the minister, Dr Kemp. I ask you: has there ever been a minister for youth affairs more out of touch with young people than Minister Kemp? This is a man who has been contacted 12 times by AYPAC since his appointment and has refused to meet with Australia's peak youth body. This is a man who got a staffer to inform AYPAC by telephone, half an hour before his announcement, that every single cent of AYPAC's funding would be removed. Yet this is where politics in Australia appears to be heading. If young people seek to defend their rights, abolish their organisations. If environment groups criticise the blackmailing sale of Telstra, remove their funding. And no doubt, soon, when the government has its One Nation lackeys in this place, Aboriginal and multicultural organisations will be axed as well. I understand that AYPAC will launch a bite-back campaign in the wake of this decision, and I can proudly declare that the Greens (WA) will support AYPAC in this endeavour, every step of the way.

Is this the first time the government has acted in this way? No, actually it is not. Groovy, radical and funky organisations like the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation have been defunded as well. We have mentioned environment groups, and not exactly radical environment groups like the ACF have had their funds cut. We have had organisations like National Shelter defunded. Could it be they have criticised the federal government's housing policy?

We have had migrant groups picked off for having dared to be progressive in their viewpoints. We have had the Australian Community Health Association defunded. How dare Environmental Defenders choose to litigate against the government. Considering most environment laws can only be acted against the government, how dare they criticise by way of litigation. How dare they be concerned with those really important things like test cases, which the government should be funding in the first place in the public interest. What a dreadful thing for them to do—to speak up for the community. The Migrant Women's Association: heavens, fancy talking about the workplace relations impacts on migrant women. Whoops, they go as well.

Has it occurred to the government that, if you keep doing that in every sector of the community that you affect, eventually what happens is that that dissent, that level of mistrust, will bubble up to the extent that people no longer trust governments any more? Has it occurred to the government that the strongest governments are those that have the strongest oppositions? The strongest governments are those that are prepared to listen to and promote criticism.

It has been put to me that there have been three stages so far in relation to lobby groups in Australia. We know that when the previous Labor government started its term of office, there was the ability for many organisations to lobby; in fact, the government encouraged that. After a while, they too became arrogant and they said, `We don't fund you to lobby. You fund your own lobbying, but we will still give you residual funding.' Now, the government says, `We don't fund you to tell us what is wrong with our policies.'
I would like to finish with a quote from an Australian Council of Social Service press release in relation to AYPAC. The ACOSS President, Michael Raper, said:
The Minister has cut funding to one of the most effective advocates for youth in this country.
The timing of the decision relates to the youth allowance. He continued:
The Government
should recognise that silencing the voices in opposition does not reduce the negative impact many of their policies are having on low income and disadvantaged people.
It does not make those issues go away; it just means that you will lurch from crisis to crisis, and you are not learning.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased today to rise again on a theme that I consider vital to Australia and to its future—youth policies and the representation of youth interests in government policy making.
—And crushing critics!

—In 13 years of ALP government, Senator Carr, Australian young people were neglected and ignored. Their needs were swept under the carpet, their futures disregarded and their situation completed overlooked. The ALP churned our young people through training program after training program. That they managed, but they refused to put in place the sound economic policies that would give our young people a job. They spent our young people's future and they nearly mortgaged this country out of existence.

speech.para: Of course, we have the fine record of the now Leader of the Opposition, then employ ment minister, Mr Kim Beazley, when, in 1992, our young people faced a seasonally adjusted youth unemployment rate of 34.1 per cent. Many people just stopped looking for work, and you cannot blame them. Giving up looking was hardly surprising when you consider the options that the ALP provided for these young people to seek jobs. We had the CES with its oh so impressive less than 20 per cent success rate, with less than a quarter of the sites that our job network now provides and with less than 20 per cent of all vacancies listed.

The things Australian young people said about the CES are a disgraceful indictment on the people who sit on the benches opposite. They show how significantly the previous government let them down. One young person from an employment network provider in Footscray said, `Here I feel like a person whereas at the CES I felt like a number.' The previous government made our people feel like numbers and offered them no sense of self-worth or self-respect. For over a decade, they consistently failed young people. Their message to our young people was that the dole was an acceptable alternative to education, training or employment, and that seeking further opportunities was simply not worth the effort.

When the coalition promised that a cabinet minister would be given the responsibility for the youth affairs portfolio, we sent a powerful signal that we would be different and that we would listen to young people's concerns. In government we have proved this over and over again. We introduced work for the dole, which will expand to 25,000 participants for each of the four years starting in 1998. We have dedicated $61.8 million to work for the dole this coming financial year, and 80 per cent of the places provided will be targeted to the 18- to 24-year olds. The aims of work for the dole are clear and provide good support and encouragement for Australia's young people. All those participating in work for the dole are acquiring the skills, the abilities and the confidence which employers seek. They are also getting the opportunity to extract themselves from the sticky web of unemploy ment that was so common under the Labor government.

We are assisting young people in getting the education and training they need to get a job. If young people are finished year 12 or have some training or qualifications, research shows that they are far less likely to experience unemployment. That is something that I think people on all sides of this chamber should applaud and encourage. The coalition is working to make our young people's lives better. It is giving them every opportunity to realise their full potential, and we are working towards this goal in consultation with young people and their chosen organisations. Senator Stott Despoja's proposal for discussion today is not concerned with the government's overall record in the area of youth policy—a record the government would be proud to debate, but I dare say the Democrats and the ALP would be somewhat reticent to do. It is targeted directly at the issue that the government's contract with the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition will end on 1 July. Senator Stott Despoja's assertion that AYPAC has been defunded is simply mistaken, as we have already heard. Their contract was for three years.
